That is one takeaway from this novel, along with the truth that we are all connected, whether we like it or not, and our moments of heart, of caring, even when imperfect, are all that stands any chance of healing the wounds of the world. That sounds cliche when I write it here, but as this novel unfolds, it comes forth as a deep truth slowly revealed, and is anything but cliche.'

author: b'Cynthia'
title: b'What a disappointment !!'
body: b'I hate leaving a one-star rating for anything by JK Rowling - especially a book I was so excited about reading, but after, literally, forcing myself to finish this book, I can\'t give it anything more than one-star.  The book was long, very boring and I spent most of the book waiting for something to really happen.  But, the ending seemed very abrupt and incredibly depressing.  I certainly hope this isn\'t the kind of book that she\'ll feel the need to write more of.  How very disappointing !!  Its not very often I feel "sorry" about reading a book, but this is definitely one of them.'

author: b'Garnet Reviews'
title: b'Magical Writing about Muggles'
body: b'J.K. Rowling is a true wordsmith.  This book can be read simply for the joy of experiencing how she puts sentences together.  The story is full of insights into the inner workings and self absorption of characters forced by the nature of their birth into society to behave in predictable ways.  It is sociology and psychological insight at its best.  The critics probably scanned the book and found something "ordinary" in an "ordinary" town in a short time span.  Nothing blows up, no death eaters, so they are dissapointed.  I could not put this book down.  I found myself laughing and marveling at some of the ways the language can be used, by the self-importance of the characters.  There is someone you know in this book, someone from your town.  I thoroughly enjoyed this book but I am a student of human nature and excellent writing.  Just a wonderful book.  Can\'t wait for more, J.K.'

author: b'Colleen Loehr, M.D.'
title: b'I was transformed by reading this novel'
body: b'This is a brilliant and powerful novel. With fearless accuracy Rowling describes what is ugliest and then goes deeper- drilling down to the deepest truth of all- the inexplicable beauty hidden in ugliness. In life we go through changes, and the characters in this novel go through deep changes- and I changed with them. As human beings we are saddled with selfishness and smallness, yet sometimes the walls of egotism are torn down and something  surprising comes through. The last several chapters build up to a crescendo ending. Without sentimentality or shallowness, going down into the grittiest of human experiences, J.K. Rowling manages to find jewels of redemption.'

author: b'Mary Lavers (in Canada)'
title: b"So, uh, it's fine...you know...it's okay...but hey! Don't we all just love JKR so much?"
body: b'It was never a question of whether or not I would read J.K. Rowling\'s first novel since the Harry Potter series, and her first book for adults. Obviously I would read it. I\'ve been a huge fan of Rowling\'s writing and storytelling for well over a decade, reading and re-reading the Harry Potter books more often than I have any other book (let alone series of books). She\'s been a big part of my reading life for years. Obviously I would read anything she writes. As some reviewers have said, she\'s "review-proof." I, like so many others, would read her work no matter what. The question is, could I write an honest review?'

author: b'Ian'
title: b'The Casual Vacancy'
body: b'Boring characters poorly developed that failed to engage the reader. Too much inane, detailed, conversations that after 236 pages, well, this vacancy remains unfilled.'

author: b'Kindle Customer'
title: b'Like running a marathon without getting a glass of water at the end.'
body: b'I am neither a fan of the Harry Potter series or not a fan. I read them at the time my granddaughters and niece were reading the series to keep up with the books that had "taken over" their young lives. While I didn\'t find the Potter series to be especially well written, I always kept in mind that it was written for children. The Casual Vacancy is not a children\'s book and should not be read with the same kind of expectations.'

author: b'Pandorasecho'
title: b'Lumos'
body: b'Of course all the reactions that are in all the other reviews of this book happened for me.  I was delighted that JK Rowling Was going to be publishing another book.  I was sad and unbelieving and hopeful and worried when I heard that it would not be part of the Harry Potter universe.  I am after all a functioning, adult woman, who just happens to also be a major Potterhead.'

author: b'Caroline Niziol'
title: b'Solid Mystery Novel from JKR'
body: b'If the vast amounts of outrage in the reviews on Amazon are any indication, this book was not what people expected next from HRH JKR. Its only elements in common with the Harry Potter books are teenager protagonists and a British setting. Despite many warnings and careful marketing of the book to an adult audience, cries of vulgarity appeared almost immediately.'

author: b'InvisibleMonkeyhouse'
title: b'Not for everyone, but a satisying read nonetheless'
body: b'A Casual Vacancy, the long awaited adult novel from Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling is a different kind of book. Not only is it as far as possibly different than the HP series, it is also a book that is different from all adult novels. If you are looking for something similar to Harry Potter or a good wholesome read like the Potterdom was...put this book down and head to the teen section. This is a black comedy novel FOR ADULTS and even made me as an adult a little nervous at times. Not to put too big of a spoiler on things but there is rape, sex, scandal, child abuse, drug abuse, and lots of British jargon to hold it all together (think tracksuits) in this small town.'

author: b'Simply Keith'
title: b'Brilliant, Disturbing, Not for Everyone'
body: b'Having read some of the more negative views, I have to say this:  Would you have ranked "1984", "The Bluest Eye", "The Grapes of Wrath", or "Great Expectations" so badly? Guess what, some of the best stories aren\'t fun-filled light reading!  Some of the best works are disturbing, even sad. So, if your view of literature is that a book can only be worthwhile if you can breeze through it having a fun adventure, then don\'t bother with this book.  This is something else entirely.'

author: b'L. Horn'
title: b'Make it through the first 25% and it gets better'
body: b"If this had been written by anyone other than J.K. Rowling, I NEVER would have finished it.  The first quarter of the book was truly awful.  I hated all the characters and there were way too many of them to keep track of, as well as the book just being filled with unnecessary vulgarity.  However, at about the 1/2 way point I realized I didn't hate it anymore and by 70% done, I was actually enjoying it and wanted to find out how it ended."

author: b'Jane'
title: b'Most of the book is petty, unpleasant people hurting others.  The ending is sad and depressing.'
body: b"During the first half of the book I took a lot of notes, more than normal.  I didn't know who was going to be important.  It turned out almost everyone was important, so I needed those notes.  There were nine households with parents and children to keep track of and additional characters as well.  By the middle of the book I was wondering when are things going to start getting good?  Later in the book I was impatient for it to be over.  The last thirty pages were the best, when interesting things happened to two characters.  One stood up against obstacles and made a difference.  One saw beneficial changes in her circumstances.  But for all the other characters, things just continued as before.  There were a few minor changes, but nothing that grabbed me."

author: b'E. Migliori'
title: b'Disappointing'
body: b'I was sorely disappointed with this book.  I am not an avid HP fan but enjoyed the books and the movies.  I was well aware prior to purchasing that this would be a book for adults.  However, I expected an R rating, not a XXX.  There was really no way to know how objectionable the content could be prior to purchasing.  I gave her 2 stars for being an exceptional writer but other than that could find nothing redeeming about this book.  There is simply no reason to stuff every political-social-economic topic available into 500 pages of print.  The characters were polarized, not dynamic the way most people really are (ex. Snape), with their good and bad qualities. Many reviewers may object, but I feel like JKR does have somewhat of an obligation to consider the audience that brought her so much success.  Those who say she should be allowed to just follow her "creative muse" are those who like it.  Also what about the HP readers transitioning into adulthood who pick up this book?  It is being sold by the cash registers in my local BJ\'s!!  There should be a sticker on the cover indicating strong adult themes.  In addition no excerpts were offered of the book so that the reader could get an idea of what they were getting into.  Many authors offer that prior to the book being released.  All-in-all, I felt duped. And yes, I object to the Kindle price - probably determined by her publisher (I am not sure).  It seems somewhat disingenuous for a women who gained her early success while on welfare, to now be charging an arm and a leg for a book, much more than most authors, for a book with controversial content.  I am an avid reader, and spend thousands of dollars a year stocking up my kindle.  I looked forward to this book with much anticipation and it fell far short of anything I expected.'

author: b'Scott E. Hendrix'
title: b'A truly great novel'
body: b'I will warn anyone thinking of buying this book  on the basis of their love of the Harry Potter novels that they may well be dissapointed. Those were fun books and enjoyable to read, but this is a truly great novel. I\'ve seen reviewers who pan it for being "plodding," a novel in which "nothing happens." I would have to disagree, and do so strongly. Yes, there is not a great deal of action if one means that term in the way it is applied to Hollywood movies. But every page is filled with engagingly deep character studies and fascinating insights into the human condition. It amazes me the way in which Rowling paints a portrait of a town that is so outwardly idyllic, but in which there is so much seething conflict seemingly hidden behind every door and every hedge. Along the way she encourages us to think about what goes on within the human psyche, to consider waht drives the people around us, to be sympathetic toward, or at least understanding of, the flaws that we all possess.'

author: b'bandcandy'
title: b'Shades of Black: a world without hope.'
body: b"The myth of Pandora's Box tells of how the box contained all the evils of the world - but at the bottom was Hope. In Casual Vacancy the author gives us a cast of deeply selfish characters who between them exhibit pretty much every vice in varying degrees and commit acts of cruelty and depravity both great and small. What we are not given is any sense of hope. At the end there are hints of repentance and reform, but the book has taught us not to trust such things. Even apparent acts of charity are portrayed as being motivated by selfish reasons. The town of Pagford is a town peopled by grotesque caricatures, where no one can be trusted and compassion is a chimera."

author: b'Maryellen'
title: b'Good Girl Gone Great'
body: b"Let me start by saying, this is the first book I've ever read by this author.  The FIRST.  It will not be the last."

author: b'bgg'
title: b'vulgar'
body: b"I loved the HP series and hope this might be as good. There is enough trash out there I was very surprised at the vulgarity she used. I tried to keep an open mind but the trash continued and I gave up after the first 100 pages. The story line itself was OK but just because a novel is 'adult' doesn't mean it has to be that vulgar. Novels for adults do not need to use such language."

author: b'Verified Amazon Customer'
title: b'another excellent book by J.K. Rowling'
body: b'Great book! I preordered it. Not Harry Potter but still great storytelling by a genius!'

author: b'tara'
title: b'no HP..'
body: b"but then again, that's the point. Harry Potter and The Casual Vacancy really need to stop being compared; they are different in almost every possible way. The Casual Vacancy was by far not the BEST book I've ever read, but it was worth buying and reading. I wouldn't say I particularly enjoyed it, as the subject matter is tough, but I did find myself wanting to get back to it when I took a break from reading. The writing is strong, and the characters are developed well. Their personalities are clearly displayed and their inner struggles are gripping. While their actual lives may not be amazing and interesting, that also is part of the point of the story."

author: b'Tracy Wormald'
title: b'Slow starting but great read'
body: b'I loved this book.  It was slow starting and took a while to figure out the characters, but its gritty and well written and the story will stay with you long after you have put the book down.'

author: b'Donna'
title: b'Jk---- stick with Harry Potter'
body: b'This was a terrible waste of my time and money!  It did NOT live up to the hype.  I kept reading thinking it would improve....it  didn\'t !!!  Reading this book was "painful".  Couldn\'t wait till the end.  VERY disappointing!!!  jK should stick with a Harry Potter sequel!!!'

author: b'Amazon Customer'
title: b'Horrible book'
body: b"I feel compelled to review this book.  This book is the most depressing book I've ever read.  I finished it hoping to find something redeeming at the end but was disappointed.  I can't believe anyone would find this book enjoyable.  Story of dysfunctional families with no joy anywhere to be found.  Very depressing.  I won't be buying another book by this author.  What a shame after the Harry Potter series."

author: b'Brian'
title: b'Really disappointed'
body: b"Really disappointed. I started this book with a blank slate, forgetting everything about her previous books. I gave it a try, and even started reading it a second time.. thinking I didn't read it properly and perhaps that is why it wasn't very good. No. It's just not very good at all. Avoid at all costs."

author: b'T. Foster'
title: b'Petty, selfish, unpleasant people and their disgusting behavior'
body: b"This book is filled with petty, selfish, unpleasant people and their disgusting behavior. I'm an avid reader and certainly don't expect my novels to be nothing but sweetness and light, but this book is utterly unpleasant. It's a character-driven novel, but none of the characters are likeable or admirable in the least. This is not a story of good people fighting bad people; it's a story of disgusting, self-centered people interacting with other disgusting, self-centered people. The story jumps so rapidly from one character's POV to another's, I didn't feel invested in any of them; didn't know them; didn't care about them. I actually had to write notes to remember names -- who was whose son, wife, enemy, etc. There is very little plot; no causes or quests I cared about. It's filled with vulgarity in language, thought, and deed. I'd give it an NC-17 rating. I was ready to plow through the unpleasantness out of loyalty to Rowling, but realized around page 120 that, not only was I repulsed by these people, I was bored out of my mind. Rowling is a gifted writer, especially at describing people, personalities, and attitudes, but this novel is page after page of small, petty behaviors, not major actions that move the story forward. When one of the charcters started scratching his hairy navel, I decided I was done. I skipped and read the last two chapters, which were so depressing and pointless, I'm glad I didn't waste my time on the rest. So so so disappointing! Argh! Does Rowling really think the world is filled with nothing but vulgar, miserable people? I heard her describe this novel as a tragic comedy. Well, the comedy is very subtle indeed."

author: b'Harry potter lover'
title: b"Book ruins Rowling's literary legacy"
body: b"What a disappointment.  Stock characters. No recognizable hero/heroine. No creativity. Nothing special. Save your money, and don't waste your time on this very ordinary book by an author who wrote an extraordinary series."

author: b'robb quick'
title: b'Moving'
body: b"I don't generally write reviews as books are extremely personal. I do make it a point to read Amazon reviews as the reviewers could be your next door neighbor or another published author.  I was introduced to JK Rowling by my two nieces & loved every book.  This book is nothing like those novels.  Readers need to forgot who wrote the book in order to allow this novel to be viewed on it's on merits.  Yes, there are a lot of characters, but unless you work alone in your home, most of us touch the lives of countless others in our daily routines. And yes, many of the characters are unlikeable, but we all know unlikeable people, some of us ARE unlikeable people.  That said, after being introduced to the characters and how their lives were interwoven, it was very hard to put the book down.  (I am one who will read a few chapters, and if not engaged, will stop reading and move on to a new book.)  I didn't like these people, I felt pity and disgust for them, but I needed to see how their lives intertwined until the final page. I was not disappointed."

author: b'Peter Eerden'
title: b'Well done Jo. I will be back for more'
body: b"Having just finished reading `A Casual Vacancy' By J. K. Rawlings I was interested to get a feel for the reviews already out there before starting on mine. Polarised is the first word that springs to mind. Comments such as:"

author: b'Gabriella West'
title: b"Like a 19th-century novel in many ways; Rowling's treatment of class goes deep"
body: b'The novel is partially about Pagford\'s children warring against their parents, and that is certainly an enjoyable subject, one we can all relate to. But Rowling is not content to depict middle-class adolescent rebellion. She goes even deeper, exploring a family from the Fields housing estate, whose daughter, Krystal Weedon, goes to school with Andrew and his unpleasant friend "Fats" Wall. Krystal barely has a family at all: a mother, Terri, who\'s a chronic heroin addict and former prostitute, a little brother who is learning disabled and neglected. One of the most powerful scenes in the book is when social worker Kay comes to interview Terri and tries to get through to her that her son is in danger of being taken away. Terri is barely there, a wispy wretch of a woman who can scarcely form a coherent thought. Yet Kay, enmeshed in her own personal problems, has this unexpected insight: "But not to feel, not to care... Right now, Kay thought, she\'s happier than I am."'

author: b'Kaycee12'
title: b'It is OK'
body: b"I am a huge HP fan so I had to get JK's new book. I have to say that there are too many characters which makes it confusing. The story also isn't that interesting."

author: b'Amy D.'
title: b"Wish I'd downloaded a sample first"
body: b'I don\'t think I would have purchased this if I had downloaded the sample for the Kindle first.  But I respect JK Rowling\'s talents so much that I just bought it.  She is much more talented than this.  Whether a book for kids or a book for adults, this is not worthy of Rowling.  So far, I am reading through a litany of character "development", but have not found one likable character.  Except for the reaction to the death of the council member, there doesn\'t seem to be a plot, and frankly, I wouldn\'t care what happens to any of these people if there were.  For someone so talented at creating DIVERSE characters and memorable locations, this is completely underwhelming and forgettable.'

author: b'WEB'
title: b'I like it. A lot.'
body: b'I wasn\'t entirely sure what kind of book I was buying when I picked up Casual Vacancy. The buzz on it had been vague. I heard that it was a mystery, and then that it was about teenagers, and of course that it was "for adults."'

author: b'Mad Hatter'
title: b'Good Book Gone Bad.'
body: b"I watched an interview with J.K. Rowling and became very interested in why she called it a book written for adults and if you didn't cry at the end, she had nothing to say to you...  That was enough mystery to get me to download the free sample on my Kindle.  I was reading at a very good clip and knew I had to find out how this was going to end so  I bought it.  I was hooked and could not put it down in the beginning but somewhere in the middle it became mostly centered around teenage preoccupation along with an extreme overuse of crude language that was no longer necessary to build the characters.  Too many character dysfunctions made it more distracting than intriguing.  And so-called 'big secrets' I found laughable - not shocking.  It's almost as though the Author couldn't decide which of her good ideas she wanted to focus on so she threw everything in there and unfortunately, in my opinion, it became cluttered and lost its momentum.  It's a shame.  One of the questions in the interview was whether or not it would become a movie to which she said, no and now that statement makes sense. Bottom-Line:  I feel mislead.  I feel this was  written for teens in mind - not adults.  And I paid top dollar for a book that sadly, wouldn't be surprised to see in the discount book area by Christmas."

author: b'themadpotter'
title: b'The Casual Vacancy'
body: b'This book was very disappointing.  I loved the Harry Potter Series, the humor was wonderful in that story.'

author: b'Kim'
title: b'Forget Harry Potter when reading The Casual Vacancy'
body: b"I'll admit that I only picked up this book from the library because it was written by J. K. Rowling and it was actually available when I arrived at the library. I did not intend to read it so soon after it was published and I had very low expectations for it."

author: b'J. jacob'
title: b'Dull'
body: b"Very confusing, I'm 1/5 of the way through and want my money back. With her talent in other areas of writing Rowling should stick to children's books."

author: b'SSM'
title: b'Incredible Waste of Money'
body: b"After having read and re-read all the Harry Potter novels, I was eagerly awaiting Rowling's first book for adults.  I expected a well written novel, with characters I cared about, deep themes, food for thought, and a satisfying conclusion."

author: b'Loves to read'
title: b'Ok'
body: b'This book dissapointed me mostly because none of the charecters were likeable. The focus was always on the worst part of humankind. I was aware going in that this book would be written for adults and not children, but the use of some profanities and descriptions seemed almost crude.  It was still well written from a literary sence, just not enjoyable.'

author: b'EF Sweetman'
title: b'Uninspired attempt to un-Rowling herself'
body: b'I love how nearly every review either claims to be HP devotees or Never Read\'em. No middle of the road here. Same with Ms. Rowling\'s sorry sophomore slump in THE CASUAL VACANCY. I have to think her success with the Harry Potter series made her such an untouchable icon to her editor that no one felt powerful enough to tell her "These characters really stink!" JK Rowling\'s uber success with Harry Potter was her ability to craft people the reader not only cared about; they were adored, wept over, debated, imitated...ad nauseum. I read this mediocre novel just waiting for redemption but feeling through out the entire piece of indestinguished drivel that the author strove with every detached description to be OPPOSITE of what made her great. As a result this novel was lacklustre, plain-vanilla, and somewhat amateurish. Back to the drawing board, Rowling, and find someone who isn\'t dazzled by your wealth and past to whip you back into writing shape!'

author: b'Kevin Drummond'
title: b'I lasted 200 pages'
body: b"Don't bother buying this book if you are a HP fan.  Way too many people to understand what was going on."

author: b'Gini'
title: b'From someone who has read this book and appreciated it as a stand-alone novel, drawing no comparisons to Harry Potter.'
body: b'I am an avid reader, however I never make reviews of the books I read on amazon, this is the first one I am posting. I felt that I needed to do something to try and fight back against all these unwarranted 1 star reviews (which I have read through, and find their points appalling).'

author: b'Amazon Customer'
title: b'A rollercoaster of emotion.'
body: b'I loved this book.'

author: b'ann.r'
title: b'J.K. Rowlings Ordinary people in The Casual Vacancy'
body: b'It is difficult to write an interesting book about ordinary people.  However, ordinary people deserve to have their stories told.  The characters in The Casual Vacancy are ordinary people.  Some are ordinary middle-class  adult and teenage dwellers of pretty Pagford leading ordinary lives for their circumstances.  Others are ordinary classless adult and teenage dwellers of the neighboring run-down Fields public housing development leading ordinary lives for their circumstances.  Human suffering does not distinguish between class or age.  All suffer in The Casual vacancy.'

author: b'Brandon'
title: b'Trash.'
body: b"I knew not to expect an award winning book, but this book was just a little overboard on how it was written. The book was written like it was forced to put adult content into it, the book was very choppy and didn't flow. Again I knew not to expect an award winning book but I was expecting a decent story to enjoy."

author: b'Mrs. Marian'
title: b'The Casual Vacancy'
body: b"J.K. Rowling's latest novel is a compelling story of the downfalls of class distinction, small-town pettiness, troubled marriages, angry and immoral teens, and the effects of abuse and poverty.  It is raw and painful; an insight into the struggles of people with no meaning in their lives beyond what is here and now.  J.K. Rowling is an amazing author, but I was so disappointed that her first 'adult' novel was so full of gratuitous smut.  Harry Potter went through life at Hogwarts never once having to relieve himself or take a bath, but in this novel we get descriptions of every sort of nastiness out there.  The main characters were supposed to be the adults, but Rowling's teens are the driving force in this novel, as well as the source of most of the vulgarity and disgusting behavior.  Why is it that today's authors seem to feel the need to add vulgarity and smut to their work in order to be read?  The Casual Vacancy covers nearly all of humanity's ills in lurid detail.  I can fully understand drug abuse, pornography, teen sexuality, child abuse, infidelity, and pedophilia without being dragged into the back bedroom to witness it. The last third of the book told the same story without all of the x-rated descriptions that were shockingly present in the early pages.  Though I appreciate the message and the reality of those who would overlook a small boy left alone, I won't allow my girls to read it, and my brand-new hardcover is going up for sale.  I am so disappointed."

author: b'Thoughtful Design'
title: b"A slow read ~ not up to JK's gold standard"
body: b'Expectations for Rowling are enormously high.  If this book had been written Maeve Binchy, we wouldn\'t be as stingy with praise.  But this book is written by JK Rowling, the Literary Queen of England.  I am a huge fan so I grabbed this book via Kindle download as soon as it was available.  It\'s taken me nearly two weeks to finish it.  The storyline is slow to develop and the characters are not very engaging.  There are some definite plot twists at the end and some compelling moments, but overall it\'s just a slow read and an "okay" novel.'

author: b'R. Sherwood'
title: b"I'll never see this in a high school library"
body: b"It's clear that J.K. Rowling is done with unfolding the shining wonder of the magical world.  She plunged also into the darkest depths of her magical world, and is in need of a change of pace from that as well.  The Casual Vacancy is her exploration of the banal and ordinary, the flat concrete grey in contrast to the brilliant chiaroscuro of the light and dark of her Harry Potter books.  There is no hero, no villain, in this book, but rather a small town full of characters of varying importance and qualities.  Their concerns could not be any more petty and unimportant to the greater world.  Everyone hates each other in The Casual Vacancy, and the most positive reaction I felt about any character was pity.  The rest of them I despised more and more as events progressed.  They all enjoyed each other's suffering, and I could hardly care, either, and yet Rowling still managed to make me cry at the end."

author: b'Angela'
title: b'Good read/listen'
body: b"I recently finished listening to Casual Vacancy.  I was sorry to see it end. I found the book realistic, dark in places, character driven - hard to put down and also fascinating. Yes this is an adult book - and JK Rowling explored some intense issues sometimes graphically - yet she also explored some dark places in the Harry Potter series (which I also have read). The main characters are fully developed and multi faceted. I was never bored. I recommend Casual Vacancy for someone who wants to immerse themselves in a story and is willing to read about realistic, human foibles. My only complaint was ( as someone here also mentioned) I wish it could have been longer. Write on JK Rowling - I'll keep reading and listening."

author: b'Faith Marston'
title: b'Loved the book, wish it had been a bit longer'
body: b"This book is very character dominated, it took me about 5 chapters just to figure out who everyone was, but after that I couldn't put the book down. I found all the characters not necessarily likable but for the most part they felt real. There seemed to be a bit of poetic justice in the end when Howard has a heart attack and ends up being in the hospital for a long time.  The ending left me hanging a bit and I wish that it had continued on a bit more and not ended on such a sad note. I kept hoping that Barry Fairbrother would end up not being dead and would pop up at the council meeting when they voted on the Fields and Bellchapel. I thoroughly enjoyed the book the writing was excellent and the entire book was very descriptive. I found a few typos in the book mainly parentheses that shouldn't have been there. I was amazed, however, at the number of one star reviews from people who hadn't even read the book and were only complaining about the price. If you don't like the price don't buy it, but don't give it a one star review when you haven't even read it. Reviews should be for one's opinion about the book not for venting because you think it's too high priced. I thought it was well worth the $17 because the hardcover was $35 at the bookstore. I will definitely read it again. Can't wait for her next book!"

author: b'Gail  Grosvenor'
title: b'a dark but so real story'
body: b'as a huge harry potter fan i could not wait for this book. the story was good and kept me reading but if you are looking for magic this is not the book for you. it is a story like a maeve binchy only darker. i do hope she continues to write.'

author: b'Sophie the empath'
title: b'Amazing book, Rich, loving, enriching, magical, but not for TV junkies'
body: b"First off, JK Rowling is one of the best if not the best writers of prose I have ever read. Her prose is like poetry: no wonder that the uneducated, unpolished, sleepwalker doesn't like it."

author: b'Amazon Customer'
title: b"Shouldn't have been published!"
body: b'If this book was written by anyone else no publisher would have printed it.  My thought is that this was an initial attempt at writing long before her popular series, and was published under the theory that her name alone would create millions of copies sold.  Alas, we fell for it.'

author: b'M. Grigsby'
title: b'Yuk! Just Yuk!'
body: b'When I discovered that J.K. Rowling was writing an adult book, I was thrilled. I did not have unrealistic expectation by thinking this talee would be sweet and mysterious, I expected good writing,an interesting plot and a marvelous adventure. Unfortunately, what I received was a vile and painfully dissapointing read. After reading 380 pages, I felt so disgusted and dirty I had to stop reading the book.'

author: b'Lakelady'
title: b'Get It From the Library'
body: b"I wish I had checked this one out from the library and not purchased it for my Kindle.  Had I borrowed it from the library I wouldn't have even finished reading it and would have just returned it after the first 100 pages.  Boring, bleak and dark. Extremely predictable ending.  At least in the HP books good always wins over evil.  In Casual Vacancy nobody wins at anything and you keep waiting for her to pick up the pace, but it never happens.  All in all a waste of time and money."

author: b'Thomas W. Altizer'
title: b"Skip the e-book, it's a ripoff!"
body: b'I paid $17.99 for the e-book and see that now it is available for $3.00 less.  As irritating as that is, it doesn\'t hold a candle to the irritation caused by the basic disfunction of the electronic edition of "The Casual Vacancy."  The day after I paid the inflated price for the Kindle version, a software revision was made available to correct margin errors.  Since I hadn\'t started reading it yet, I downloaded the revision.  The revision however fails to hold the bookmarked pages and every time I go back to the book I have to spend time trying to manually locate where I left off reading.  Highly irritating, particularly at the very high, subsequently discounted price.  As for the story itself, it\'s engrossing enough to keep the reader engaged and is a true departure from Rowling\'s brilliant "Harry Potter..." books.  I recommend the book, but do yourself a favor an buy a hardback copy.  The e-book is a real dud.'

author: b'T. Outler'
title: b'Takes forever to get into!'
body: b"This is a 500 plus page novel which I read on my kindle. It took me 77% in to enjoy the book. The last 23% was great. But the average person isn't going to hold on so long for a story to grab them. It does get great at the end. And there are several brillant moments in this book. If you are looking for a Harry Potter keep looking!!!"

author: b'Tyson Peveto'
title: b'Such a Richly Rewarding Read'
body: b"I loved this book. It was one of those far-reaching novels covering so many characters in the small town of Pagford. Rowling slowly builds up this house of cards, this Jenga tower, intertwining all the characters (the cards or the blocks, whichever metaphor you prefer) into everyday life. Then, she starts pulling a card here, a Jenga block there, until Pagford's pretty facade is completely destroyed."

author: b'BeachReader'
title: b'Surprised me'
body: b'I had a hard time getting into this book. Yes the language can be crass and there are uncomfortable moments. At times I thought, why am I reading this? But then I realized I was having a hard time getting the story out of my head. It still makes you think long after you finish. Are the characters likeable?  No. But society has so many people like this. JK Rowling really surprised me with how deeply this story has stuck with me.'

author: b'Jordan Hofer'
title: b'Excellent representation of human politics'
body: b'Rowling captures the political human animal and the war between its individuals as accurately as Frans de Waal does chimps in'

author: b'richard 75'
title: b'A cup of tepid tea'
body: b'I am not a particular fan of fantasy fiction, although I gamely read the Harry Potter series with my children, so when I heard that JK was coming out with a novel void of giant serpents and smoking wands, I looked forward to reading it immensely. However, by page 20 I would have given my left nut for even one glimpse of a flying motor car or slithering snake.  Rowling offers up a bland assortment of tedious townspeople who she never  developes in any interesting way.  Flat characters,a dry narrative style and predictable plot made this story a dull afternoon with a cup of tepid tea.  Sorry JK, but perhaps you should confine your writing to the hallowed halls of Hogwarts after all.'

author: b'Rachel B'
title: b'BORING'
body: b'I was terribly disappointed.  BORING and certainly not up to her creative abilities.  I hope that she will please return to what she does best.  HARRY POTTER and his future trials and tribulations.  I am 73 and Harry is one of the most fascinating series ever!  Rachel'

author: b'Live to Read!'
title: b'This is not Harry Potter!!'
body: b"Don't buy this book if you expect Harry Potter. My daughter has read them all and loved them. She's seen all the moves, and we've been to The World of Harry Potter."

author: b'Stevek2000'
title: b'Worst book with illegal price fixing'
body: b'This book started slow, but by the middle you actually think it was faster on the beginning.  Hope the publishers get sued out of business by the justice department, for price fixing.'

author: b'Tim'
title: b'Not very good'
body: b'I bought this book because of the author.  I was very disappointed in the book.  I kept reading, hoping that it would get better or exciting but that never happened.  I liked the idea behind the book and it sounded like it would be good so i preordered it.  What a waste of $17.99.  I noticed that today it dropped to $14.99 but it is not even worth that much.  It seems like someone that has written the Harry Potter series could have come up with a better story than this.'

author: b'P. D. Cantrell'
title: b'Absorbing story, interesting characters'
body: b'I read this book in audiobook format:'

author: b'Moose Spot'
title: b'Sadly disappointed.'
body: b'Before give my opinion I want to tell you I think J. K. Rowling is one of the most talented writers I have ever read. As an individual, she has gone through incredible trials. I love that she has generously given back to organizations worldwide. She has encouraged children to read and stands up for the rights of those who have been abused throughout the world. She is an amazing person.'

author: b'nanofoster'
title: b'Vulgar and wordy'
body: b'This book is certainly not worthy of the time spent to read it or the hefty price you pay at the register.  It strikes me as an explosion of seven books worth of fowl language and gratuitous sex that the author previously could not use.  There are times when you have to reread sentences to get what she\'s saying because she\'s trying to be clever or its over the top "descriptive".  Did not finish it even though I paid $30 for it.'

author: b'T. J. Tenholder'
title: b'Not so much fun.'
body: b'This book was a bit of a chore for me to read. To me it is a sad story about sad people in a dreary place. Tweek it a little and you could have a Robert McCammon novel. Some of those drag on, too. Some readers like that kind of stuff. If you are one of them, go for it. Or, perhaps read Bleak House, it costs a lot less.'

author: b'Mary Elliott'
title: b'Very dull plot'
body: b"I'm afraid I just can't go into the lengthy reviews that some people had. There isn't that much to say about this book. I thought the plot was dull, although I did enjoy reading the British term for things and their way of turning a phrase. While I loved the HP series (and yes I DID know this would be completely different), I was very dissatisfied with this overall."

author: b'Shay'
title: b'Over the top...'
body: b"This is a harsh book about the reality of divisions in small towns. There was substance at first then the book became to scattered. The use of such crass language was not necessary. The characters were over the top. I  don't live in the UK but a small town is a small town. Big fish, little fish mentality is not explored as in-depth because there were to many characters.I would not recommend buying this book but borrowing it from the library..."

author: b'catherine'
title: b'heartbreakingly enthralling'
body: b'having just finished this book, i feel heartbroken finishing it after feeling as if i became a part of the Pagford and Yarvill community-i felt the pain in Krystal Weedon and the desperation and smugness of a community and the constant need for gossip-each character is relatable and we all see bits of ourselves in each of them. i am a lover of the HP novels and reading this-not expecting magic but the superb writing of Rowling was completely on par.'

author: b'John Hodges'
title: b'None'
body: b'Very disappointing book. Author needs to stick to writing books for non adults. Dull muddled read. Sorry I wasted my money.'

author: b'CBP the bookworm'
title: b"Harry Potter this isn't - but it isn't meant to be"
body: b'As a longtime Rowling fan, I was intrigued by the synopsis of Casual Vacancy, and curious to experience Rowling\'s mastery in an entirely new genre.  But I think I had fewer expectations than some other readers that Rowling\'s adult work would be "nice".  It isn\'t.  And that\'s ok.  A writer whose work for children was accused of being "too dark" and "too scary" isn\'t going to write something sweetly pretty for adults.'

author: b'Robert Niles'
title: b"Amazing - J.K. Rowling's turn as an English William Faulkner"
body: b"Just finished The Casual Vacancy - an absolutely stunning book. This is J.K. Rowling as William Faulkner - introducing tons of characters, then letting them stew in a stuffy, self-important, backwater town. There's a theater cliche that if you put a gun over the mantlepiece in the first act, someone'd better fire it by the end of the second. In the final 40 pages, Rowling unleashes a fusillade - tying together all elements of her soap opera into a gut-wrenching ending that manages to be both inspiring and an indictment at the same time. Well worth reading."

author: b'J. Christian'
title: b'Wonderful, engaging, all-encompassing read.'
body: b'I kind of think maybe she should have written this book under a (different) pen name. That way there wouldn\'t be so many whiners complaining about how "I loved Harry Potter but this was just not my style" and gave the book 1 star. It\'s unfortunate when an author can\'t write in a different style without the masses exclaiming she should have just left it at Harry Potter. If you can\'t stretch beyond your tiny box of what type of books you read, or you can\'t overlook that the "Queen of Harry Potter" wrote this novel, or you don\'t like contemporary novels, or you don\'t like anything that makes you uncomfortable-with-ugly-topics, perhaps you should save your trouble and not buy the book and then leave a horrible, undeserving review.'

author: b'Ryan G'
title: b'Why would she ruin her reputation?'
body: b'After reading initially what the book was going to be about, I wouldn\'t have bought this book except that it\'s by J.K. Rowling.  I mean, she is the hottest author on the planet, why would she risk putting out a dud unless it\'s a sure thing? Why would her management and team of people around her allow her to put out something that wasn\'t an immediate success?  After 25 or so pages in, I thought, "Ok, this is Rowling, the story telling is great, but man, this book is NOT good."  Any other author and I would have put it down.  75 pages later, I can\'t go any farther.  I\'m finished with it, can\'t get through it.  Good luck to the next reader and hopefully her next book is much, MUCH better.'

author: b'Sharon Furstenwerth'
title: b'We forget where J.K. Rowling came from ...'
body: b"J.K. Rowling could write an insurance policy and I'd read it - cover to cover . Do not read this book to be uplifted. It is stark reality, and she captures the small town microcosm as well as she captured adolescence in HP. There were really only two characters in the book that I didn't like, and the book is full of characters and how their lives interweave. Most, however, were shown to be human - with all the hearts and warts attached. She not only writes about our prejudices, but she writes about how tragic events can turn lives around, can heal relationships, and can break people apart. This book is like old age - it's not for sissies. If you love J.K. Rowling's writing, however, it is for you."

author: b'TonksGrrl'
title: b'Still working her magic!'
body: b'I hate writing a review that gives things away.'

author: b'Joseph Horton'
title: b'too bad'
body: b"Not good.  It's a soap opera in a book.  And it's not a good soap opera."

author: b'Mieke van Reader'
title: b'Entertaining effort'
body: b"I just finished JK Rowling's new book and I have to say that in spite of some shortcomings in the editing, I really enjoyed it.  Yes, it could have been a bit shorter and yes, it is dark.  The characters (and there are more than enough of them) are well drawn, though unfortunately, there is not a sympathetic one among them.  But sometimes life is like that. The sex, drugs, violence and foul language rang true and were not used to titilate or shock.  That's just how things are in the places Rowling writes about."

author: b'Katherine S McKee'
title: b'read it'
body: b'Fantastic read in a contemporary setting. The characters had depth and the story reminds us all how we are interconnected.'

author: b'L.'
title: b'Fantastically Written'
body: b'I am very, very close to the end so I think it is okay for me to make an accurate review.'

author: b'Zoe'
title: b'DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY!'
body: b"I feel betrayed.  The only good thing about this book is that I got it at the library and wasn't out one single cent."

author: b'Msreadseverything'
title: b'big flop'
body: b'This is the first book (kindle version) that I seriously considered returning.  While I have bought bad books in the past, I at least bought them in hard cover so I could donate to someone else or to a library.  I read widely in many different topics, types, from fiction to non-fiction, from classics to new ideas.  It is almost like I want to scream...enough building of the characters already...is anyone ever going to do something???? I will admit I am about 1/2 through the read...and I find myself starting to skim...so I can just say I finished it...sure wasted my money.'

author: b'kathysaysso'
title: b'Surprisingly awful'
body: b"This book is tragic - not in the literary sense.  Every last cliched character was despicable.  I actually began to dread reading further because I was bored by the unrelenting sordidness.  Halfway through I had the thought that perhaps she had meant this to be a black comedy.  But there wasn't a modicum of humor to be found in the relentless depictions of abuse, hatred, suffering, betrayal, physical ailments, and crummy weather. A waste of 17 bucks on my part, and talent on hers."

author: b'Jay'
title: b'Life, Loss, Pain, and Redemption'
body: b'They are all there.  Rowling puts together a story that deals with the class differences and idiosyncracies of life in England. Snogging, shagging, and all other kinds of words we usually don\'t see on my side of the pond. I thought the story was extremely well crafted. It took a couple of chapters for me to adjust to all of the characters thrown into the story, but they were all distinct enough to be be interesting.  Think of a world where Jane Austen re-wrote "The Wire"... minus the police angle.  Social issues abound and are looked at from all sides.  I honestly thought the book was fascinating!!  I highly recommend!!'

author: b'Rose Shannon'
title: b'I am SO moved by this story'
body: b"This is my first experience with J. K. Rowling. I can only hope she continues to write adult books.  I am an avid reader...how many books have I read in 60 plus years????  Cannot even begin to guess. This book, The Casual Vacancy, is in the top 10 of all time on my list.  I had a slow start because I am normally a mystery, thriller advocate.  Soon, I was swept up into all the characters' personalities, lives, conflicts.  This is not a romance novel..... it is about individuals' shortcomings, misunderstanding of intent and subsequent fall-outs.  The frailty of the human spirit, the pettiness, fears, cruelty of the human psyche and how all of these affect people's lives.  Ms. Rowling's writing skill is so remarkable.  She has taken a group of characters and their lives and placed them into a clear order and class structure within the confines of a small town in England. I KNEW each of these characters, their relationships, their weaknesses, their dependencies. Because the author is so skillful a storyteller I felt like I was actually there and witnessing these events.  Bravo! Bravo! Bravo! Great movie material."

author: b'LouCocks'
title: b"So Happy The Newest Harry Potter's Finally Been Released!!!"
body: b"I just got this book in the mail, and I just can't wait to spend all night reading the newest Harry Potter!"

author: b'A. KAPLAN'
title: b'A Portrait of Ordinary Lives'
body: b"JK Rowling's first novel for adults is a complex, detailed portrait of an English village, told through the vehicle of a local election to fill the casual vacancy on the parish council left by the death of Barry Fairweather. Rowling has created a complete setting that feels very real, with a geography and history and society that make a concrete impression in the reader's mind. And she's populated it with a very diverse cast of characters (well, mostly white, if I'm honest, but diverse in background and personality) whose lives I really started to get wrapped up in."

author: b'lawk'
title: b'Brilliant and I hate it'
body: b"JK captures brilliantly the everyday life in England that I grew up with. However, I hate this book because it brings back all the ghastly memories I prefer to forget. This is why I left England to become an American citizen. I admire JK's courage to write this book. It captures history and 200 years from now it will probably be read along with the books of Jane Austin and Charles Dickens who captured the everyday life of England in their time."

author: b'Lisa Mason'
title: b'The not-so-casual vacancy'
body: b"It took me a while to finish this book.  I almost put it down and didn't complete it before I had read 50 pages, so shocked was I by the perpetual f-bombs and vulgarities of the characters.  I honestly didn't like the book at all at first.  I'm glad I finished it, but I also told my 17 year old son that I didn't want him to read it.  It is very much a book for adults, and I'm concerned that parents will buy the book for their Potter-loving children.  It is an innocence-robbing book."

author: b'Ferret Fan'
title: b'Dislike the whole concept; dull, boring.'
body: b'I was so looking forward to reading this book and so disappointed in the content.'

author: b'bookworm100'
title: b'Not up to HP standard'
body: b'I am a HUGE harry potter fan, and was very excited about this book. I ordered it months before it was released. I was very disappointed. It has a lot of swearing in it, as well as a lot of sexual references, and I did not make it very far into the book. One thing I really loved about the harry potter series was how clean they were. This is so close to a different writing style I would not have suspected it to be written by the same author if I had not know previously.'

author: b'Marilyn Olowe'
title: b'A gritty and intelligent human character study'
body: b"Wow. Just wow! One of the grittiest and most intelligent human character studies I've read in a long time."

author: b'BestChickLit.com'
title: b'Brilliant'
body: b"Not once did I think of Harry Potter while reading this book, and because of that it deserves a review based on its own merits, with no comparisons drawn with its sibling novels. The Casual Vacancy is captivating in every aspect and is sure to be set on my bookshelf of favourites for years to come. Each character has a deep backstory with realistic motivations behind their actions. You might not like everyone, but that is the whole point of the story. It is reality. Pagford isn't full of witty characters who have exhilarating adventures; it is a representation of real life, with its foul language and dubious intentions and each character has their own responsibilities to face or avoid."

author: b'Ajay'
title: b'Real, Gritty  and Eminently Readable - Rowling Triumphs once again'
body: b"I have been having a bit of a laugh by reading all the negative reviews on Amazon. Firstly, we had a whole lot of people whinging about the ebook price. Now, we have a whole lot criticising its 'filthy' language."

author: b'J. Terry'
title: b'Sharp, Biting, Dark, (sometimes) Funny -  A Worthwhile Read'
body: b"As I write this, the bad reviews for The Casual Vacancy outnumber the good reviews.  That's too bad, because this is a well written book, one that is certainly worth reading."

author: b'Kindle Customer'
title: b'So disappointed'
body: b"I had been really looking forward to this new book from a talented author.  I stared reading it and couldn't continue.  It was so base and disgusting.  The language was terrible.  I didn't find any redeeming qualities in the book or the people in the book."

author: b'Margery L. Goldstein'
title: b'A well-constructed, well-written, but dark book'
body: b"This dark but engaging novel has one thing (at least) in common with the Harry Potter books: it deals at length with the disconnect between the actual lives of teenagers and how those teenagers are seen by their parents. The teens in the village of Pagford are not magical, but they do have a power their parents don't recognize: they are comfortable with computers. One after another, they hack into the parish council website to wreak havoc with their parents' lives and reputations."

author: b'Lynne Millar'
title: b'awful'
body: b"Wow, I can't believe I actually finished this book. I kind of feel like I need to go boil my brain. There's a lot of language and whatever else you can imagine that's adult in this one - but actually the bigger problem for me was the unrelenting, soul-sucking cynicism and negativity. I kept reading because I was waiting for something to shift, for her to show some little glimpse of redemption or hope for ANY of the characters... something to give meaning. It never really happened until the very very end, and by then, it was just waaaay too late."

author: b'charliebower'
title: b'disappointing'
body: b"Though her humanity and empathy for the human spirit remain, Rowling's wit,taste, charm and wonderful humor are lacking in this book.  The heavy topics are dealt with in an offensive manner.  I'm disappointed in this book, and think she could do much better."

author: b'Chris'
title: b'Read 100 pages, requested a refund'
body: b'This is the first time that I have ever requested a refund for an ebook from Amazon. This book has so many characters, long back stories for everyone and is incredibly boring. I loved the Harry Potter books, but this was terrible.'

author: b'Virginia Conterato'
title: b'Depressing and full of awful people'
body: b"I don't usually write negative reviews, but this book was a huge disappointment.  The characters were stereotypes.  There was little in the way of plot, and everyone in the book was miserable.  Many were actively trying to make others miserable."

author: b'mariposa'
title: b'brilliant social commentary'
body: b'this book is not for the shallow reader who merely wants entertainment. this book will uncover deep dark secrets in your own mind you didnt even know you had.'

author: b'Mary'
title: b'Rowling writes with depth about loss, class, small towns, etc.'
body: b'J.K. Rowling writes death so accurately; only those who have directly experienced an unexpected loss will immediately recognize and absorb the exact rightness of it.'

author: b'T. Floyd'
title: b'Disappointed with the subject matter'
body: b"I have only read the first half of the Kindle sample.  I am returning it unopened and unread and regret having pre-ordered the book (first time ever with Amazon).  I wish the book description had been more forthcoming about the subject matter and themes.  I didn't expect Harry Potter but I did hope for the same rich literary style, symbolism, and uplifting themes of the HP series.  Life can be dark and ugly but also light and redeeming.  From the reviews I have pored through good and bad there seems to be nothing terribly positive in this book or its resolution. One big Jerry Springer episode.  I was turned off by the characters even before I hit the crude language in the sample chapters and chose not to finish and delete the sample.  There was no hook to keep me reading.  I will wait with anticipation for her next work and hope that is something more inspiring and with more likeable characters.  I love JK Rowling's writing, just not this particular path she has chosen to take.  Maybe next time--but I won't be pre-ordering."

author: b'C. Meyer'
title: b'Took it back'
body: b"I bought this book for my 23yo daughter as a birthday present.  One day later she asked me to take it back because it was filthy.  She has no interest in reading the F word all the time.  They say it is J.K. Rowling's first book for adults, but what gave her the idea that truly mature adults want to hear the F-bomb all the time?"

author: b'S. Ham'
title: b'Listen and Learn'
body: b'Men vs. Women'

author: b'Amazon Customer'
title: b'a train wreck'
body: b'There have been many eloquent reviews already which echo my thoughts on this book.  I was not expecting a rehash of Harry Potter, was forewarned it was for adults and had few expectations.  However, I would have put this book down several times out of disgust and boredom, had I not hoped that somewhere, somehow, a little bit of redemption would be present.  I wish I had put it down at some point rather than force myself to keep reading.  Glad I had it from the library.'

author: b'Ella Green'
title: b"Rowling's Best"
body: b"I can't say how happy I was to see this side of Rowling. She has definitely matured as a writer since her first book, and it was great to see her writing at her full potential, in a way she could not while writing Harry Potter. This is an honest account of life, and a great example of how the life of one person can be so deeply entwined with that of others."

author: b'ArianneMartell'
title: b'Not what I expected.'
body: b"The casual vacancy is not usually my type of book, and it got me time to get into it (around 20% in, I think), but once I did, I was really glad I stick with it. How she handle the characters is very interesting and the ending kind of shock me actually. It was really nice and I'd recommend it."

author: b'L Ramsey'
title: b'No Way'
body: b"I haven't read the book yet. Just sharing that no way am I going to pay $18 for a Kindle book, no matter who wrote it. I'll put myself on the waiting list at the library. I'll adjust the stars after I actually read it."

author: b'Lyn Russell'
title: b'A modern Dickens.'
body: b"An engrossing and well crafted expose of middle class complacency and prejudice.  I couldn't put it down and look forward to further adult fiction from Rowling."

author: b'high flyer'
title: b'Huge disappointment!'
body: b"I loved JK Rowling's style of writing in the Harry Potter books. This book reads like it is written by a 16 yr old.  I am only halfway through and will finish it only because it cost so much. Do NOT waste your money or time on this one."

author: b'Kelly L. Hensley'
title: b'I feel bad for J.K. Rowling...'
body: b"...who has a built-in audience with a set of expectations.  She was writing for a very different set of readers in this book.  I haven't re-read the Potter series or listened to the audiobooks for a while, so I was interested to see how her strengths (description, plot) and weaknesses (wordiness, love of adverbs) as an author translated.  From what I'd read of the book pre-publication, I didn't expect any magic or sly allusion to Harry's world."

author: b'Tony Burson'
title: b'A cast of true characters'
body: b'I was born in England and lived there for 28 years, this is the England I left and have seen during many visits to Derbyshire.'

author: b'Kindle Customer'
title: b'Great Disappointment!!'
body: b"I only read the first 10 pages of this book.  I was totally disappointed.  It is full of foul language which was really offensive.  I don't know anyone who actually uses that kind of language. I truly believe any author worth reading should have a good enough grasp of the language that they can express themselves without using foul words!!!!  A book considered 'adult' does not have to be full of offensive language to make it 'interesting'.  Also it seemed to be a very wordy, slow moving story. I deleted it from my kindle fire!  If I could give it a negative amount of stars I would."

author: b'JOHN A SHAW'
title: b'no magic'
body: b'I found myself thinking "who was this character" after 150 pages.  It was a hard book to pick up and very easy to put asside.'

author: b'jack'
title: b'dont bother'
body: b'Just finished this book. My advice to all would be dont buy it!!! If Amazon would take it back I would send it immediatly back.'

author: b'J. F. Stepnowski'
title: b"Can't finish it...."
body: b'Alas, I WANT to like this.  I am not put off by the language or adult content.  I am getting tired of having to thumb back through the book to remind myself who, exactly, several characters are - I am getting some of them mixed up with each other.  I find myself wishing for a character list at the front of the book (like you get in some big fat old Russian novels ;-) ).  I am on page 143 and so far have found not one single character I can give a hoot about - not one seems sympathetic or to have redeeming qualities that would make me want to keep reading to see what happens to them.  Sigh.  Page 143 and I think I am done.  :-('

author: b'Autumn "From the TBR Pile"'
title: b'It was just ok...'
body: b'When Barry Fairweather dies it opens up a casual vacancy on the city council.  A casual vacancy is defined as a situation in which an unexpected opening occurs on a political board, as in the case of a death or disqualification.  Mr. Fairweather\'s death throws the town of Pagford into turmoil to say the least.  The town has been divided for many years over the issue of "The Fields" and under which jurisdiction they should reside.  Do the residents of The Fields reside in Pagford and use their resources or do they belong to the neighboring, larger town of Yarvil?  Currently the populace of The Fields is made up of low income, government dependent residence so many in Pagford would like to see them sent to Yarvil, Barry Fairweather is a popular resident of Pagford and he came from The Fields and he has made many good argument about why the people of Pagford need to take care of the people of The Fields.  The death of Barry Fairweather heralds a change in the weather for the anti-Fields clan and they are eager to fill his seat with a candidate sympathetic to their cause.'

author: b'Ann M Beasley'
title: b'Depressing book'
body: b'I picked it up on the reputation of J.K. Rowlings previous books. I will not be picking the next one. This is a very depressing book. There is no plot, it is just s character study of a small town and not one of the characters are likeable. Halfway through the book I was thinking, "okay, I get it" and hoping that something would happen but it never does.  Don\'t waste your money on this book. It is not clever or entertaining.'

author: b'Lynn Dye'
title: b'The warnings were true'
body: b"I was excited to hear Rowling was writing again and eagerly ordered this book at my local library. Before I picked it up, I started reading some reviews and thought, 'oh no, this doesn't sound like something I'd like'. Sure enough, I started the book and read the first few chapters and then I knew I would NOT be finishing this book. Instead, I skipped throughout the book reading portions of it and now will be returning it to the library."

author: b'Nannie'
title: b'Disgusted Reader'
body: b'Seldom have I ever been so disappointed with a book.  I have read and re-read all of the Harry Potter books and I guess I was expecting a book of their quality.  Boy, was I ever wrong.  I have been privileged to teach for 44 years and also serve as librarian.  I bought this book because my high school readers were wanting more J. K. Rowling.  Before I got past page 14 in the book, I had to mark out copious inappropriate words.  Young people are exposed to inappropriate sights, sounds and words in their lives.  They absolutely do not need to see them in the works of a beloved author.  Shame on you, J. K. Rowling.'

author: b'Grammcracker'
title: b'Disappointed by Content'
body: b'As fabulous as a writer as J.K. Rowling is, this book is simply not for me. The "f" bombs and sexual content (which were unnecessary to the plot ( as usual) , had me walking away. Thankfully , I used the Amazon Kndle option of reading the sample before I purchased the book. This is one Rowling book that will never be part of my library. For those of you who enjoy a good book without the junk I hope this review helps.'

author: b'E. Taylor'
title: b"I laughed & cried & couldn't put it down"
body: b"I thought this was a fabulous story! VERY well written, not a word wasted. JKR has a very sharp perception on human behaviour & it's in full force here. Her writing reminds me of a less twisted & dark Roald Dahl. Highly recommend for those who appreciate great writing."

author: b'M Gerrish'
title: b'A Very Sad Place'
body: b"One can't escape knowing about J.K Rowling, her difficult background, her stupendous success with Harry Potter. I never read more than a few pages in one book from the series, which presented itself at my nephew's bedtime. I was unimpressed, it felt tedious, although I have enjoyed the movies."

author: b'Ron Nagy'
title: b'Casual Vacancy'
body: b'Casual Vacancy is one of the few books I ever threw in the garbage. I read 70 pages of dull, negative, poorly placed foul language before it hit the garbage can. I would not classify "Adult" because of the foul language that was forced or better yet deliberately placed so this book would seem Adult. Definitely not an up lifting feel good book or a book I would recommend to anyone.  J Rowling has ruined her reputation and certainly we adults will never again buy our wee ones a Rowling book. What was Rowling thinking when she was writing this book????'

author: b'Dan H.'
title: b"Haven't read it, Wont read it"
body: b"Sorry, but this is one more example of my frustration at having purchased a kindle.  $17.99 for a blast or electronic digits.  $17.90 for a brand new hardcover.  People can talk about it being Publisher's fault all they want.  Paying more, even nine cents more, for a digital version over a hardcover is simply wrong."

author: b'Leslie A. Daley'
title: b"'JK Rowling' by name ONLY"
body: b"First off, I'm a complete and total 110% Potterhead.  I love the series, loves the book, can read them over and over and never tire of them.  When I found out JK Rowling was publishing an adult book, I pre ordered it the moment Amazon let me.  I recieved it the other day literally jumping up and down for several minutes before I hurried ot my room to begin reading it."

author: b'J. Yu-Sian Wang'
title: b"Story doesn't call me ... lots of vulgar, swearing, cursing language"
body: b'I love Harry Potter, and have been delighted with the Potter Universe, the characters, the environments, and the story.  Somehow this story is just not interesting to me.  I read thru the "see inside for a quick peek" ... it still does not call me.  I don\'t doubt that JK Rowling had put together great prose and great observations, but I just can\'t read through it without falling asleep. I guess I\'m just not  that interested in provincial English country life or something like that.'

author: b'JMP'
title: b'VERY Boring book'
body: b'As an adult, I read all the Harry potter books and enjoyed all seven of them.'

author: b'mimi'
title: b'standing ovation for J.K'
body: b'I enjoyed this book so much, I didnt want it to end. The way J.K knows to describe all the thoughts that go through all of us and at the same time does not stop us from judging others..she is an amazing writer. A lot of small sentences are so condense with so much of the human truth. i loved the book, i really did. bravo!'

author: b'Shelley Morrill'
title: b"DON'T READ THIS!!!"
body: b"I feel like this book was an over correction from Harry Potter, like she was out to prove she doesn't just write about kid stuff by fearlessly writing about the most terrible aspects of human nature.  Maybe someone will feel that's heroic.  I feel it's pointless and unnecessary because it's been done.  A lot.  The plot is simple and I see what she is trying to say, but it is overdone and becomes dull and cliche.  Many books of this genre aim to inspire one to do better and change the world.  This story just makes me depressed.  There is no humor to cut the sadness.  I dislike/hated most of the characters and only a couple I could tolerate.  Why would I read a story with an unoriginal plot and unlikable characters that makes me feel depressed by the first 100 pages?"

author: b'LitChick'
title: b'Rowling is a literary master. Keep in mind this is not HP.'
body: b'As someone who appreciates literature, Rowling amazes me with her talent. Once you put it out of your mind that this is not the wizarding world of Harry Potter, you can appreciate the stunning images of real life invoked from her syntax.'

author: b'J. Conneely'
title: b'IF YOU SEE YOURSELF, TRY NOT TO FEEL THREATENED'
body: b'I gave the book 4 stars instead of 5 because of the slow start.  The editors should have  prevented this, especially for such a high profile writer.'

author: b'O. Lindy'
title: b"I'm so surprised!"
body: b"The writing style is completely different from her past works - if I didn't know that JK Rowling wrote this, I would never guess she is the author.  Her range is impressive.  The characters are completely fleshed out, the language is strong but true, and the setting is so close to reality, as realistic as HP was fantastical.  I am reading The Goblet of Fire with my son, and to switch between the two books was interesting to say the least.  I am very pleased to have read this book and look forward to reading whatever else JKR decides to publish."

author: b'DB'
title: b'Bold Call For Help For The Kids Who Are "Have Nots"'
body: b'I think the author could have rested on her laurels after her unprecedented success with Harry Potter.  However, instead my take is she felt called to action to point out this problem of the "haves" and "have nots".  For more than half way through the book I was thinking it was mediocre at best.  But by the time I finished it, I came to realize it was a bold, brilliant way to get us to think about the "haves" and "have nots" and how inside people\'s minds, daily thoughts and hearts they are all the same no matter which side of the tracks they live on.  Granted all of the people in this book were messed up, alhough Krystal and Kay did try to help others.  My guess is since the author has achieved unprecedented success, she has met people in high positions she would not have otherwise met and she has been unimpressed or even disappointed.  I think Rowling\'s bottom line is there are "have not" kids out there dealing with real problems such as drug addict parents and some of the people who appear to the be pillars of their towns, schools, etc. are not helping them because they fill their days with all of the nonsense/shortcomings we saw in the book.  Yes, I bet the next book will deal with more social issues.  And yes she will probably offend some people again as she attempts to influence them to action.  I think it is her way of giving back after all of her success.'

author: b'Sean P. Endress'
title: b'"The books that the world calls immoral are the books that show the world its own shame." - Oscar Wilde'
body: b'Rowling\'s "The Casual Vacancy" is, in some way, indeed aimed at her prior audience. The children that grew up with Harry and company are now in their early twenties, the demographic which this reviewer believes will have the most interest in this work.'

author: b'Julie Merilatt'
title: b'Meh'
body: b"Once you get past the novelty of a beloved children's author using vulgarity and narrating drug use and sex, the book is relatively mundane.  The plot lumbers along at a moderate pace, introducing characters of the town of Pagford and outlining their situations.  While Rowling excels at character development, the townsfolk in this novel are unsavory, bordering on detestable.  Junkies, wife beaters, ambitious small-town politicians, despondent wives, and horny teenagers make up this cast.  Once everyone's intrigues are presented, the pacing slows down for the latter two-thirds of the book until the last 40-ish pages.  There's a mildly tragic and somewhat climactic conclusion, but by the end, I just wanted to be finished.  There were some decent little sub-plots and some deserving characters got their comeuppance, but the daily minutiae of Pagford was monotonous."

author: b'Lane'
title: b'A Beautiful Satire from a Matured Author'
body: b"Rowling's writing style has matured. Her goals as an author, too, have come a long way."

author: b'Donna'
title: b'Secrets, Sabotage, and Scandal or Oh the things muggles get up to...'
body: b"Casual Vacancy tells the story of a small community in the aftermath of the unexpected death of one of its community leaders and council members, Barry Fairbrother. Several of Fairbrother's peers are ready and willing to fill his empty council seat but not everyone is happy with the nominees. Suddenly this small town is like an episode of Gossip Girl as somebody claiming to be Barry Fairbrother's ghost begins posting on the council's website and outing all of the member's dirty little secrets (XoXo) And while all of the adults are plotting, planning, and pointing fingers, who is watching their kids? These parents may have underestimated their teens' resentments as they focus all of their energy on their position in the community."

author: b'Joan V. Finman'
title: b'SO DISAPPOINTED!'
body: b"I WAITED SO LONG FOR ROWLING'S NEW BOOK TO COME OUT..........I WAS SO VERY DISAPPOINTED IN IT, RIGHT FROM THE START....I'M NOT SURE I AM EVEN ABLE TO FINISH IT.  IT IS EXTREMELY BORING.  PERHAPS SHE SHOULD STAY WITH MORE BOOKS LIKE HARRY POTTER, I THINK THAT'S WHERE THE MIND SET SHOULD BE"

author: b'JMK'
title: b"I loved it, and don't understand what people were expecting."
body: b'If more people had approached this book with an open mind, I think it would have gotten better reviews. Despite being told again and again that this book would be nothing like the H.P. books, some people obviously expected something similar. I also think if you understand something about the British sensibility you will like it better too. I\'ve read lots of British authors works and if I had to compare her work to someone else\'s, I would compare it a bit to Faye Weldon\'s body of work. In my humble opinion, there is a greater divide between the "haves" and the "have-nots" in England. Rowling (and Weldon) love skewering the upper classes high opinion of themselves. In The Casual Vacancy, the little town of Pagford wants to cut financial support for a drug clinic in the Fields, which lies between Pagford and Yarvil. Pagford fancies itself the quintessential quaint English village, they don\'t want the taint of the Fields associated with their town. Of course the fact that a lot of the people in Pagford have roots in the Fields is something they\'d all rather forget. Rather than realizing how lucky they were to escape the fate of most Fieldians and trying to help others improve their lot, they want to distance themselves from the people and problems of the Fields. It illustrates how quickly some people can forget where they came from once they get a little money. The biggest exception is Barry Fairbrother, who is from the fields, but lives in Pagford and serves on the town council and is trying to help one girl in particular, Krystal Weedon. Krystal is a perfect example of someone whose life could have gone either way. You get the feeling that if Barry had not passed away, Krystal may have had a chance. You see how easily someone can give up on themselves if no one else believes in them. I don\'t want to give anything else away but I think her characterizations are just a tiny bit caricatured but otherwise they seem pretty spot on. I hope Rowling writes many more books for adults and I hope she is not influenced by bad reviews to write fluff just to please people who\'d rather not have a glimpse at a side of life they\'d rather not know exists.'

author: b'aeb'
title: b'REAL characters, and an effective message about society as a whole.'
body: b'The Casual Vacancy opens with the death of Barry Fairbrother, a prominent citizen of the tiny village of Pagford and member of the Pagford Parish Council, and follows by introducing all the various characters of the book (citizens of Pagford) and their reactions to his death. Although I didn\'t find it boring, I felt as though the first third of the book or so contained so many new characters written from so many different points of view that I felt like the first third of the book was more an introduction than anything, and it was a bit hard at first to keep all the names straight and remember who was who. The action moved very slowly and I found myself wondering, "What is going to HAPPEN in this book other than meeting a lot of (albeit very interesting) characters?"'

author: b'Rita Mayberry'
title: b'Good story, just a little long.'
body: b"I am enjoying reading The Casual Vacancy by J.K. Rowlings. I like the character development -- she is indeed a master and getting inside a character's skin and showing what makes him or her tick. This certainly must capture modern life in a small British community.  I am hardly an expert on that, but, lets face it, J.K. Rowlings certainly is. It matters little, though, where the story is set."

author: b'Norman R. Goos'
title: b'Not worth the time and money'
body: b"The book was somewhat cute, a maze of subplots coming together for a flat ending.  It was not as well written at the Potter series.  The author's knowledge of British hamlet life today and it's street talk was impressive, although it did nothing for the story line - Krystal et al became boring.  Over all, it would have been a good $5.00 paperback to speed read on a flight, but there was no substance."

author: b"shay's #3 fan"
title: b'soooo disappointed'
body: b"not a reader of Harry Potter...thought I'd try Casual Vacancy....I think the reviewer who wrote she'd rather drink drain cleaner has it just right...I have read more than half this depressing, miserable tome and just can't go any further.  What a disappointment---The publisher should provide tranquilizers...or good stiff drinks...or just tell the eager buyers....it's dark, dreary, depressing..."

author: b'A. Ackerman'
title: b"Couldn't Do It"
body: b"I was so excited to see what Rowling would do for her first adult novel, and I'm greatly disappointed.  I couldn't get into the story at all.
