There were way too many characters and I couldn't keep them all straight.  But more importantly, I didn't really care to.  None of the characters were interesting - they all seemed so depressing!  So yeah, I didn't finish it, and even if you tell me it all makes sense in the end, I won't be picking it up again.  At least we'll always have Harry...."

author: b'JQ'
title: b'How did this happen?'
body: b'From Harry Potter to this???? I don\'t understand.  This must be the first time in over 20 years where I broke my  steadfast rule of always finish a book once it\'s started.  I just couldn\'t do it with this book.  It was too painful.  There wasn\'t a story, just one chapter after another describing one of the many pathetic characters who was "flawed" in one way or another.  It just became a chore to even open the book.  I hear enough of this kind of thing on the news.  Do I really need to read about it in a fictional book too?  I was hoping for a book that drew me into its world and I would want to find out more because I was concerned about each character.  This book was the polar opposite.  I couldn\'t care less about any of these whiny, shallow, maddening characters.  I wanted so much to love this book because it\'s J.K. Rowling for goodness sake!  Sadly, I tried my best, but I couldn\'t even get through half of it before I decided that I\'d rather be sorting socks than continue with this book.  Sorry!'

author: b'Brock C.'
title: b'Boring.'
body: b"When I received this book I was excited to see where JK Rowling would take us to this time. She never disappointed with her 7 HP books so I was pretty confident she wouldn't disappoint this time. Well needless to say I was too bored to figure out how this book ended. It was boring and I felt like the author was trying to be too edgy. It drags on and nothing really happens other than some really boring government issue. If you are seeking to find an adventure and some comedy this is not the book. It is definitely an adult book and not suitable for children. I wont bother reading anymore books in the future from this author."

author: b'R. james Tobin'
title: b"Rowling's Characters"
body: b'J.K. Rowling\'s The Casual Vacancy is raw realism, with "adult" themes: sex (not all consensual) drug addiction, cutting, not to mention smoking, drinking and profanity; also betrayal and death. Oh, yes, it is also about local politics and about responsibility for the outcast and addicted. There are many characters, few of them at all appealing, but vivid just the same. To understand what Rowling is doing here, one should remember two things: she grew up in the same part of England she is centering her story on here; and, more importantly, her favorite author was Jane Austen, who was interested in character and human relations above all.'

author: b'Booker87'
title: b'Nothing New Here'
body: b'I bought this book hoping to be entertained, but was disappointed. I was led to believe it had a comedic edge, but I failed to find anything funny in it.'

author: b'God is good'
title: b'Vulgar'
body: b'Not appropriate for Harry potter lovers.  I am an adult and was too young to read.  I quit after fifty pages.  It did not catch my attention.'

author: b'Robyn Woods'
title: b'Didnt even finish'
body: b'I dont know if its fair but Im making a review without finishing the book.  But I guess thats kind of a review in itself!  Simply, I was thoroughly bored and disappointed with the little I read. There was no reason for me to be interested enought to continue.  I expected alot more from Rowling.'

author: b'Jamieson Wolf'
title: b'A Book To Live In'
body: b'Welcome to Pagford.'

author: b'Elaine'
title: b'Just awful'
body: b"I have only read the first few chapters of The Casual Vacancy, and I'm printing out the labels to return it to Amazon.  It is awful.  Just awful.  I'd read ahead of time that it isn't a children's book, but I had no idea that meant it would be crude, crass, obscene, and profanity-laced.  And?  It's boring.  Really boring.  I expected so much more from J.K. Rowling, and I'm truly disappointed in this book."

author: b'Amelia Gremelspacher'
title: b'Portrait of a small town.'
body: b'I liked this book mainly for the character development.  Rowling does a thoughtful job of examining a small groups of people and the enmeshments that snarl their lives.  The events following the death of a counsel man, and the efforts of these people to deal with his absence, set the novel a task of explicating how these people come together.  I think a good job was done in exploring the difference between the public persona and the actual thought and circumstances of each character,  I especially like Krystal, the bad girl, whose genuine love for her brother goes largely unknown, as she becomes vilified as both "a duty and a pleasure" except by those who came to know her.  The implausible elements of some of the ending are the the only setbacks to five stars.  This novel stands up to the hype, and I wasn\'t disappointed.'

author: b'J. Ardis Cochrane'
title: b'Trainspotting meets Jane Austen'
body: b'Funny, poignant. Easy to suspend my disbelief. I doubt I would have read except from curiosity, famousest author goes feral, etc, ... But I am glad I did. Slightly weirded out by the pride and prejudice echoes in the first few chapters. Then the trainspotting parts kinda took over.'

author: b'J. Dehr'
title: b"It's clearly literature!"
body: b"Most people are probably not going to like this. It's nothing like her H.P. series. It's clearly LITERATURE and she takes a lot of time setting up the characters.  Interesting story and I enjoyed the ending."

author: b'Ms. Neroli Wesley'
title: b'Strong, revealing and not for children  -- no spoilers --'
body: b'The residents of Pagford are a motley bunch of upper, middle and working class people all stumbling through life as best they can while expressing the weaknesses and longings of humans at their worst. The most sympathetic character makes his presence felt in absence. Like Rowling he experienced the extremes of life and came up trumps fighting against ignorance, pettiness and bigotry. Many of the other characters have few redeeming features but enough of them grow for the ending to be satisfying.'

author: b'Phil Wigglesworth'
title: b'English humor triumphs'
body: b'I took a while to adjust to the tangled web of characters so clearly defined but yet at every step you are forced to readjust your knowledge of them.  This is a clever blend of revealing aspects of each life that initially make you question whether you are mixing up people, but then you realise that each person has a unique personae for each relationship and only in time do you start to see the blend that is the whole imperfect personality.'

author: b'Lexi'
title: b'Remove Expectations Before Reading'
body: b'I loved the book. It reminded me a lot of'

author: b'Cate Berarovich'
title: b'Mugglemarch? Not Hardly.'
body: b'Full disclosure, I grew up with Harry Potter and so I am somewhat biased. While the first book came out when I was only seven, but by the time Harry was defeating lord Voldemort, we were both seventeen. I was part of the generation of children who halfway expected to get an owl on their eleventh birthday, and the name J.K. Rowling was, and still is, as magical as Hogwarts itself.'

author: b'Kenneth S. Wiggins'
title: b'3 strikes and your out'
body: b'My wife has a rule about dirty jokes... they at least better be funny. If Rowling wishes to write a vulgar book she needs it to be well written and interesting. She struck out on all three.'

author: b'Alex'
title: b'Disappointed'
body: b'I was very excited to see this book and it was a major disappointment.  It was dreary, depressing and boring.  The world created in this book is not one anyone would want to visit.  I find it hard to believe that the same author who wrote the Harry Potter books could have actually written this book.  There was absolutely not one minute of joy or hope in the entire book and I disliked all of the characters.'

author: b'Amazon Customer'
title: b'Too long'
body: b'I struggled through this book because of who it was written by.  If I didnt know the author and her excellent Harry Potter books, I dont think I would have made it to the end.  It started well, but there were too many characters and they were confusing in their roles they played.  There were two really good stories in this book, but because they were in the one book I didnt like either of them.  Such a shame.'

author: b'Hayley Potter'
title: b"A proper review, by someone who's actually finished it"
body: b"I felt compelled to write this review... as I'm convinced that most people bad-mouthing this book weren't even able to finish it."

author: b'Rob'
title: b'Imagine that Harry dies in the prologue to book one'
body: b"I wasn't sure whether to give this book one star or five stars. I don't normally cry when I read books, but Rowling has made me cry three times. I cried when Dobby died. I cried when Harry went into the forest to meet Voldemort and die. And I cried at the tragic, heart-breaking ending to this book."

author: b'hema18'
title: b'\'Book for Adults?"'
body: b'I read this book telling myself that here was a new author with a new book. I was well aware that this would not be a similar offering from a well known author of a particular genre. However, I did expect the creativity and imagination that this author is justly famous for.'

author: b'Euphony'
title: b'A Sadly Slogging Satire'
body: b'A writer from The Guardian dubbed this "Mugglemarch" and I must agree the name is apt. The descriptions were decent and the "point" is a worthy one. Sadly, the tone of the story is so jaded and bitter (even if understandably so), that a spark of mystery (or dare I say magic?) would not have been amiss. I know that entertaining her readers isn\'t Miss Rowling\'s goal, but SOMETHING felt lacking and all the overworked prose and detailed descriptions in the world simply cannot disguise (what I found to be) a disappointingly mediocre work of satirical social commentary.'

author: b'Andra Jiglau'
title: b'Gripping, perfectly crafted prose'
body: b'Firstly,I am shocked to see so many bad reviews. I hope most of them are from people who expected Harry Potter, if not in genre, at least in feel : good will triumph, people have treasures in their souls no matter how hard they mutilate it etc.'

author: b'D Bloch'
title: b'nothing special...kind of a disappointment'
body: b'the positive:  it was well written and the characters were well developed.'

author: b'LindaV in Gardena'
title: b'Definitely a keeper'
body: b'The book is not for the non-serious reader, nor is it a book for simple entertainment.'

author: b'L. A. McCoy'
title: b'boring'
body: b"When I read, I want to be entertained.  I wasn't. I didn't expect or want Harry Potter, but the characters were colorless.  It may be Peyton Place vs whatever ---as stated in a previous review, but I didn't like Peyton Place either.  I kept waiting to be fascinated with the characters, but it was like a hum drum ...nothing interesting to catch my attention or make me want to turn the page......not my cup of tea.  I don't think I will finish it."

author: b'Mom22'
title: b'Too expensive for Kindle'
body: b"I have not read this book and do not intend to read it because I think the publisher has priced it too high for the Kindle. I love reading Kindle books, but the price should be lower because the books can not be shared. If I buy the book for just a few more dollars, I can share it with anyone I'd like. I prefer the Kindle version, but I think it's wrong to charge so much for an electronic book."

author: b'Booklover62'
title: b'Simply A Good Read!'
body: b'Why 5 stars?'

author: b'T. Cutter'
title: b'Make your own decisions'
body: b'If you have any interest in this book, ignore the star rating on Amazon. Most of the low ratings seem to be from people who either wanted a muggle version of Harry Potter, are upset about the price, or are outraged that there is adult content in a book written for adults. Either find a review from a publication you trust or just get the book from the library.'

author: b'Nordic Witch'
title: b'I Give it 5 SNORES'
body: b"So many great writers out there of adult fiction that can't get into print because they are unknown. But have a name and even a guaranteed sleep inducer gets published. I was told this was a steamy, adult book by the H.Potter author. Steamy? As in 15 year olds getting excited and playing with themselves? Ughhh! I gave this book too many chances to redeem itself, but with so many, many characters of which none are interesting... One reaches a point where one realizes that life is too short to be bored to death. Don't care about the characters, no reason to, since they are as realistic as cardboard cut-outs."

author: b'bookmanbookwoman'
title: b'For Adults Onlly'
body: b'"J.K. Rowling, the author of the famous Harry Potter series has written an adult story that should be read by grownups. It is big business versus those that are small and functional adults pitted against the dysfunctional. The Casual Vacancy will not disappoint Rowling\'s fans who wanted her to write something that is not for the young at heart."'

author: b'Sharon M. Galbraith Ryer'
title: b'Tightly plotted character drama'
body: b"Ain' no Harry Potter book. And if you're looking for one, look somewhere else. If, however, you are looking for a tightly plotted, intricate political drama about small-town characters who could be real people, this is it."

author: b'I. Kelly'
title: b'So bad that I like HP less than I used to...'
body: b"CV has, (according to the Kindle description) 81 characters.  Going into the book I guessed that, somewhere amongst those 81 characters, there would be someone who wasn't both boring and a terrible person.  I was wrong."

author: b'kitplanesue'
title: b'Dreadful'
body: b"There's nothing charming about this book. The foul language, low life characters, gutter scenarios and tedious story line"

author: b'ikirkwood62'
title: b'You can try to separate Harry Potter from this...'
body: b"... but you cannot. And that's not the fault of the reader, that's the fault of the author. But let's start at the beginning."

author: b'hm'
title: b"Don't expect Harry Potter, but it's a good book"
body: b'I tried to read this with a completely open mind, since I am in LOVE with the Harry Potter books and knew this probably wouldn\'t be anything like them. It was a little slow going at first, but it turns out that she is such a good writer that you stay invested even though not that much actually happens, at least in the first half of the book. If you like "slice of life" type books you will enjoy this one. By the second half, I was eager to continue reading it.'

author: b"C. O'Connell"
title: b'Sadly disappointed.'
body: b"As magical and adventurous the characters  in The Harry Potter books were, the characters in this book are the exact opposite.  Only their  dark side is shown.  In this whole  set of villagers,  there's not  one redeeming value presented.  It is probably well written,  but I couldn't see the forest from the trees.  I listened to it, and there is just unrelenting darkness."

author: b'Amanda Richards'
title: b'100 shades of "meh"'
body: b'Man down'

author: b'Viva'
title: b'What a let down!'
body: b'I am really disappointed in this book.  The story is so trite and the characters are not very interesting.  The worse thing about it is the language.  If I had wanted to read a smut novel, I could have chosen something a lot less expensive.'

author: b'Samantha Rinne Hooker'
title: b'Meh...'
body: b'Before she wrote Harry Potter, I heard she wrote a few crappy novels. Maybe this is one of them?'

author: b'C. Tyler'
title: b'Totally disappointing'
body: b"After reading the Harry Potter series, I was so happy to see another creation by Rowling.  This book is the biggest bunch of drivel I've ever tried to read.  Her use of so much shocking language and subject matter is really irritating.  She had no purpose in using this type of material other than to make it an Adult book.  The language is unneeded for the story and the story seems to have no real plot.  It is total garbage as far as I am concerned.  I do believe that teens might like it just for the tittillating passages, but adults should be offended by the way the material is presented.  When necessary to make a point, then I don't mind graphic language, but her usage is only for shock value, I believe.  It seems she believes that it is needed to make it an Adult book.  I am sorry I wasted my money on this garbage."

author: b'jeremy_david'
title: b'Adjusted Expectations'
body: b"This book is no Harry Potter, but who said it would be? If you go in expecting a masterpiece (not only with this book but with most things in general) then you will most likely be disappointed. Just start it with an open mind and be prepared to enter a world full of entertaining (if not morally detestable) people. It's a funny read."

author: b'BirdieJ'
title: b'Great read!'
body: b'I found this book to be interesting, charming, and touching.  It really draws the reader into the world of a small town.'

author: b'LeeAnne the Librarian'
title: b'Not what I expected - really bad'
body: b'This is the worst book I have attempted to read in a long time. I say attempted because I am having trouble getting through the the first half. It is dull, boring, dark, and pessimistic. Not my kind of read. I will perservere because once I start something I usually finish it. I am so disappointed because I loved the Harry Potter books. I guess I expected more from this author.  Maybe I am not English enough to understand what is going on in the book. I cannot perservere - this book is so bad - I finally deleted it from my Kindle.  I really did try to read it.'

author: b'Joan Sutton'
title: b'JK Rowling kidnapped by Muggles!'
body: b"Yes, there's only one reason she wrote this book:  she was highjacked by Muggles, obviously.  I must admit I haven't finished it yet, but my impression is that she was buried somewhere in Muggle-Land when she wrote it.  I hope she has escaped by now.  I hear she is contemplating another Harry Potter novel - GOOD!  Hope she sticks to magic from now on."

author: b'Cee Ess'
title: b'Some Vacancy - a comment on Social Darwinism'
body: b"I bought it half price (no tax). For $18.50 I figured I would read it and pass it along to family and friends. I'm not down with all the JK hype, I just wanted a decent read, and I knew she was a good writer having consumed four HP books."

author: b'Trollhair'
title: b'The Casual Vacancy'
body: b'Boring. Boring. Boring. Boring. NOT a adult book. She is still writing for children except this one has  vulgar words and sexual situations (from the teenagers no less). Her style of writing is such that  a fifth grader could read and comprehend. The book read like a bad soap opera. She even wrote it so you can move from scene to scene knowing what others are doing at that particular moment. I am still wondering why I spent two days reading this book.'

author: b'pure_predat0r'
title: b'Death is casual'
body: b"'The Casual Vacancy' showed me another way in which J.K Rowling is an intelligent, compassionate woman; it's a reflection of societies ugliness that I never would have expected from the author of 'Harry Potter'."

author: b'GPS'
title: b"If you expect Harry Potter - DON'T buy!!"
body: b'I pre-ordered this book as soon as the possibility came up, and when I received it last week I was thrilled to bits!'

author: b'wantoun'
title: b"It's quite interesting... if you manage to endure the first half!"
body: b"So first of all when you set out to read this, and you're a Harry Potter fan, you need to realize this is NOT Harry Potter in any way. You could have read a hundred novels with adult language, but seeing a couple of swear words from JK Rowling will definitely be shocking at first! You must get over all this if you want to enjoy the book."

author: b'voracious reader'
title: b'Bleak and not that original'
body: b'I am a huge Harry Potter fan and would read anything J.K. Rowling wrote.  But I probably won\'t be reading this one over and over. It had so many characters, all unlikable, that it took a long time to get into it.  Many of my favorite books have a setting or characters I\'d like to revisit.  I didn\'t find the "darkly comic" element of this book funny enough to compensate for the fact of nearly all the characters being desperate, whiny, involved in sordid behavior and endlessly thwarted.  I kept wondering what was the author\'s point in writing this book, since it couldn\'t be to tell an enjoyable story.  And the horrible details of poverty, drug addiction and various kinds of abuse are all too familiar to anybody who reads the news.  In the last 10% of the book the plot finally started to move along, and some of the characters at the end did get to grow and change.  **SPOILER ALERT**--when certain characters died tragically I was actually relieved, as they had no future and were doomed from the start by the circumstances of their lives (and also the circumstances of the book--it was hard to see how they could sink much lower and this wasn\'t the type of book where they were going to get a happy ending).  One of these characters was the most sympathetic in the book and only in the last few pages were some anecdotes revealed that added to her humanity.  By the end I thought the author\'s point was probably to draw attention to the ways in which society fails its most disadvantaged children, and that in an interdependent world this has repercussions for people from other socioeconomic levels.  She accomplished this pretty well but it wasn\'t new territory, and not the book I was hoping for.'

author: b'kfingo'
title: b'Brilliant!  JKR is Top Notch!'
body: b'This is a dark tale of woe.  There are not many characters in this books that are likeable...but there are moments of hope and light.'

author: b'Reveur'
title: b'My thoughts and feelings as a former Harry Potter fangirl'
body: b'So I just finished The Casual Vacancy by JK Rowling.'

author: b'E. Morris'
title: b'Life in Little Layers'
body: b"The reviews already tallied here have reiterated, ad nauseum, how unlike Harry Potter The Casual Vacancy is so I won't bother saying it.  What I will say is that by reading this new work, a reader of Harry Potter can see just how brilliant a writer for young adults Rowling is.  The language in The Casual Vacancy is lovely.  It is meaty, something you can properly sink your teeth into and savor slowly.  The lightness of touch she had in the Potter series is now clear, having tasted her adult fiction.  It makes the Potter series that much more brilliant in my eyes.  And it makes The Casual Vacancy that much more astounding; it is brave to venture so far from something so comfortable as a writing style one has practiced for years."

author: b'G. Cat'
title: b'Well written, grown up book'
body: b'Those expecting a Harry Potter book for grownups  will be dissapointed, but if you put aside preconceptions you will find The Casual Vacancy a well written and thought provoking book about family relationships, community relationships, and class.  The characters are not entirely likable but are complex.  It does take a while to sort out all the characters and their relationships.'

author: b'M. HARDT'
title: b'Super book'
body: b'I inhaled this book as soon as it hit my Kindle.  I did not have the formatting problems mentioned by other reviewers.'

author: b'Tom F.'
title: b'A Dreadful Book'
body: b'This is one of the worst books I have ever read.  There are too many characters and by the time you get to know who they are, you quickly realize that you don\'t like or care about ANY of them.  I did read it but could easily have read the first few chapters and then skipped to the predictable end.  I am in disbelief that JKR  put out this pile of rubbish.  I would never recommend this book and even if you can borrow it for free like I did, (thankfully,) it is still not worth your time. Go back to Harry\'s world, Jo, "The Casual Vacancy" is embarrassing no matter how much money you make from it.  Actually, all proceeds should got to charity as you deserve nothing for wasting our time with this claptrap of a novel.'

author: b'Kindle Customer'
title: b'a modern agatha christie like village'
body: b"really a great read, though it takes a while to keep all the characters' lives straight.  Rowling has a great ear for character's voices and I am amazed at how well she is able to represent different personality types, especially the teenagers.  I found it very moving and well written, not at all cliched as some have reviewed it."

author: b'Micker'
title: b'Intriguing'
body: b'I enjoyed reading this book.  It was a glimpse into the workings of a small English town.  I was amazed to find myself amazed that English people could be as dysfunctional as Americans.  I guess it really is a small world.  Although I will always miss Harry, I laud Ms Rowling for striking out in such a different direction.'

author: b'Susan Watson'
title: b'Save your money'
body: b'I spent the weekend reading this book.  I found it boring and very predictable.  I would suggest that "King of the Badgers"'

author: b'Mark'
title: b'you can return it!'
body: b'Not very good work.  You may want to know that Amazon allows you to return a kindle book within 7 days.'

author: b'skqt'
title: b'Abysmal!'
body: b'Not worth reading. Dull, cheap, vulgar, low, obscene, unrealistic, boring, humorless.'

author: b'Claire'
title: b'Great book'
body: b'I really enjoyed the Casual Vacancy. It took me a while to get into it but after a few chapters I found it very compelling. Yes, many (not all) of the characters are unlikeable once you scratch beneath the surface but I think that simply reflects reality - EVERY person has flaws.'

author: b'Marion Wilhelm'
title: b"Don't bother...it's dull, dull, dull"
body: b'JKR is such a good writer, rich descriptions, clever plots and characters that I was simply blown away at how ghastly this book was. To be fair, I simply could not even finish it and I read phone books and cereal boxes if that\'s all that\'s handy! This story moves at a snails pace, the characters are dull and lifeless and the theme is tedious. There is a it of "language" which I don\'t care about but seemed stilted and unconvincing as if Rowling wanted to convince the reader that she knew big girl words. I am sorry I purchased this book and wish I could return it. Actually I think I will return it!'

author: b'Vavek Zivota'
title: b'If you buy it, keep reading ... it gets better'
body: b'I was not sure what to expect as the follow-up to the Harry Potter books from JK Rowling, so I came with no preconceived ideas on what this book should be, or would be when I bought it.  While a bit disappointing, it was still worth reading.'

author: b'Amazon Customer'
title: b'worthy of your time.'
body: b'I loved it. I think readers of Nick Hornby, PG Wodehouse, Richard Russo, etc... would enjoy this. Ignore all the negativity. It was to be expected when switching genres and audiences.'

author: b'Willread Anything'
title: b'I was amazed how sleepy it made me!'
body: b'I could not have been more dissappointed.  I had very high expectations for this book, after reading great reviews that Ms. Rowling had done it again.  Only this time in an adult market.  Please wait for this to go on sale someplace if you really must buy it.  It is not worth the price or the time out of your daily life that you will lose reading it.'

author: b'Amazon Customer'
title: b'Man What a Book to Read So Much'

author: b'S. Family'
title: b'Trying too Hard'
body: b'I LOVE the HP books.  As an adult, I just marvel at Rowling\'s ability to weave a complex story... she just thinks of EVERYTHING.  She\'s funny, and I loved most of all the "life lessons" of good-vs-evil, with there being both real evil and real good; imperfect characters who strive to do the right thing.  We cheer for the hard but fair teachers like Minerva McGonogal and Dumbledore.  We love the devoted (though far from perfect) families.'

author: b'Kiwi'
title: b'If only Hermione can cast "OBLIVIATE" on me.'
body: b"Truthfully, I want to forget this book. Where's Hermione when you need her?"

author: b'LadyJane'
title: b'Simply trash'
body: b"Glad I tried the sample before purchasing.  After reading, and enjoying, the Harry Potter books I was very dissapointed in this one.  The language is terrible and there is no real story to it.  Maybe if I read more, but I can't abide the language long enough to try."

author: b'Amazon Customer'
title: b'A hard book, but a good one!'
body: b"From the first couple of pages of this book, it was like curling up with an old friend. Sure, there is no magic, or huge victories over evil by the side of good, but the writing is familiar and still just as powerful. The Casual Vacancy is not a happy book, it can be downright depressing, but it's an important book to read. If this book was not written by JK Rowling, it probably would not have been published, which is a real shame. Its an important story about something that is effecting most communities due to the bad economy and harsh austerity measure. The town of Pagford is a wealthy one and when Barry Fairbrother, a do-gooder on the local council dies, a fraction of people want to get rid of the poor district of Fields and the methadone clinic. Like what is happening in the UK and the US and all over, some people would rather let the little guy fend for himself rather than work together as a community to help out everyone. The characters in the book are very flawed. The reader might agree with the views expressed by one character but hate their actions in their private lives. The adults can be huge hypocrites and just down right nasty."

author: b'S. Maxwell'
title: b"If you like dark humor, it's for you."
body: b"One newspaper review I read before getting the book suggested that all of the characters are like the Dursleys in Harry Potter - mean, small-minded and selfish.  There are certainly some like that in this book, and Rowling uses them to paint a portrait of small town life in England that is alternately funny and appalling.  There's the self-satisfied and self-important parish council chairman whose chief goal in life is to cut off from his village a local housing project and de-fund the social services that help its struggling residents.  There's the middle-aged woman, trapped in a loveless, boring marriage, who secretly obsesses over a member of a boy band she sees in her daughter's DVD collection.  There's the middle manager at a printing company who terrorizes his wife and kids as though they were inmates in a concentration camp of which he is the commandant.  But there are also several characters who are well-meaning and want to do good works that don't benefit them personally - except in terms of validating their self-image."

author: b'Amazon Customer'
title: b'Disappointed'
body: b'J.K. Rowling has proven in the past to be a great storyteller.  The Casual Vacancy, however, is not her best work.  I am disappointed with the profanity and vulgar language in her book.  A good author does not need to resort to foul language and explicit sex scenes to entertain adults.  I am very disappointed with this book--I am sending it back!'

author: b'SHIRLEY GRIMES'
title: b'PRICE'
body: b'WOULD LOVE TO READ HER ADULT WORKS, BUT NOT FOR 17.99  REALLY??'

author: b'Lisa Jackson'
title: b'Too Many Swear Words'
body: b'Too many swear words. I read for 15 minutes and encountered 3 swear words. I stopped reading it and digitally returned it to Amazon Kindle for a refund due to "offensive content." If it woudn\'t have included the swear words, I\'d have continued, even though I was very bored, just because I love the Harry Potter books and have faith in the author. I don\'t read books with swear words.'

author: b"Hallie's Mom"
title: b'Disappointed'
body: b"I pre-ordered The Casual Vacancy, looking forward and curious to read a different genre written by Ms. Rowling. I could only get through about 12% of it before I quit reading it. It was depressing and it was hard to keep up with too many varied characters. I am a mature adult and loved the Harry Potter series. I supposed I anticipated a faster paced story. I would rate this book similar to many of the Oprah Book Club selections which I quit reading a long time ago. They also got to be too depressing. I don't mind a book with lots of interesting characters, but since I don't like reality shows, these characters were too much like unpleasant, conniving reality players to be part of an enjoyable read. And I do read for enjoyment because my life is real enough."

author: b'Amazon Buyer'
title: b'Very glad I took a chance on this book...'
body: b'Many of the reviews on Amazon do an excellent job of summarizing the plot, so I will not repeat that here.  Instead, let me summarize my reaction to this book and perhaps it will help others make up their own mind whether to read it or not.'

author: b'Mark from Haifa'
title: b'This book grew on me'
body: b'It took me a while to get into this book, but once I did, it grew on me, and I read with increasing interest to the end. The characters are interesting, and the author successfully developed the story of their interaction in a small English town, where lives and plots are woven together.'

author: b'Donald J. Richardson'
title: b'Essentially Trash'
body: b'While one should admire J. K. Rowling for trying to reach an adult audience, one must also retain relevant critical faculties; in this case A Casual Vacancy is embarrassingly awful. The characters are nearly interchangeable, the language is movie language (f*** with far too much regularity), and the characters are unsympathetic to distressingly negative. This appears to be naturalism to its NTH degree. Such wallowing in lower class society is not what this reader desires. He still believes literature ought to be enriching, elevating, and enlightening.'

author: b'Diane B. Wilkes'
title: b'THE CASUAL VACANCY Not A Dramatic Departure'
body: b'When you\'ve written a multi-million dollar book series that has spawned movies, merchandise up the wazoo, and miraculously magnetized boys back into the reading fold, as J.K. Rowling did with the Harry Potter books, much is expected. Loyal fans want to love the next book you write; snobby critics look forward to skewering it--"She can write children\'s novels, but..."'

author: b'Chadwick Estrada'
title: b'A dark look into a small town.'
body: b"So I just finished reading The Casual Vacancy and I really enjoy it. I know people are having mixed feelings about the novel but for me it was great read. Rowling knows how to write great story about people who are connected one way or another. Its dark tale about struggle of drug abuse, bullying, and the feeling of being trap in a small town. Its not for everyone. For me this a is great stand alone novel and I can't wait for her next novel."

author: b'FW'
title: b'Waste of time & money'
body: b'I was not expecting Harry Potter but expected much better from Ms. Rowling. Are you sure she actually wrote this? This book is a complete boor and I am returning it immediately.'

author: b'Wyomingwoman'
title: b'dull'
body: b"I had promised myself I would read at least 50 pages before I decided anything about this book because it took me that long to get into Harry Potter.  I didn't last that long.  I don't care for bad language and I didn't actually like most of the characters introduced at the first of the book.  Then I read the last chapter in case there was any redeeming qualities that would make me go back to read the rest.  There weren't.  I almost bought the book and am so glad I didn't. (sorry Amazon)"

author: b'dpappas'
title: b'Keep An Open Mind'
body: b"This is a book that I really tried to start without any preconceived notions. I banned myself from reading any reviews of this book or any comments about it from other readers (the only thing I allowed myself to read was the book's summary). Basically what I tried to do was forget that J.K. Rowling was the author and to completely separate this book from the Harry Potter series."

author: b'F. M. Pepoon'
title: b'Lack of Character Development Is the Fatal Flaw'
body: b"I am a big fan of the Harry Potter series and have read the books again and again, wondering at JK Rowling's ability to create a world so real and appealing that readers want to live there, and to create stories that are so compelling they become a part of a reader. Sadly, this book did not come close to either of those experiences. As any Harry Potter reader knows, character development is not one of Rowling's strengths, and this is the fatal flaw of the book. The teenage characters are more finely wrought than the adults (as was true for the Harry Potter series) and there are a few of these teenagers who are engaging. I wish Rowling had either focused on the teenagers' stories more or developed the adult characters. The plot is mildly interesting and kept me reading through 2/3 of the book, but at that point, the fact that I did not care enough about the characters to continue reading overcame any vested interest I had in the story line. Finishing the book was a chore, and I found the ending to be wholly unsatisfactory. I hate when authors kill off characters because they cannot figure out what should happen next, it is an insult to the readers. If Rowling had spent some time developing some of the adult characters - there are two women in particular who could have carried the book - this might have been more successful. Alternately, instead of starting the book with the death of a man who appeared throughout the tale to be one of the few with any morals, Rowling could have started with his story and had him die later, which would have created an interesting pivotal point in the plot and tension in the story."

author: b'Proud Mom'
title: b'AWFULL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!'
body: b'I read Harry Potter, but bought this with an open mind and not looking for an Adult Magical world, but what I go was garbage.  I rarely share my opinion of books, but wanted to warn readers to not waste their money on this book.  I was bored and the characters were flat and not written well.  Just save your money and buy something else.  I not only wish I could get my money back, but the time I wasted reading this.  Rowlings is good at writing Young Adult wizard novels and needs to find a new wizard to write about.'

author: b'Debi Hernandez'
title: b'Offensive'
body: b"40 pages in I found myself offended 3 times by language, alomst put it down twice before even getting that far.Boring,I am an avid reader 2 books a month,and if a book does not hold my attention 40 pages in ,I'm done...so sorry..Potter was her glory days,retirement looms..."

author: b'C. F. Bush'
title: b'Sorry Breakaway'
body: b'I am very disappointed with this book.  I was not expecting anything like Harry Potter but I at least expected the story line to be readable and to keep my interest.  I am trying to find some redeeming qualities and cannot.  I will hope, if she writes another ADULT book it has a lot more to offer her readers.'

author: b'12121'
title: b'The Casual Vacancy'
body: b'This is the only review I have ever written.  I have never felt the need to tell people to save their money on a book before.  This book is painful to read.  I made it half way through the book, before I put it down for good.  I expected so much more from this author.'

author: b'Travis'
title: b'Thought-provoking. Cozy, even. Overall fully enjoyable.'
body: b"The problem (some) people are having with this work of fiction is that they don't seem to be able to separate J.K. Rowling from Harry Potter. This book would be well-received by any other author but Mrs. Rowling's fame stemming from the very popular children's series has impeded many a critical thought. Think outside of the walls of Hogwarts, people."

author: b'abrenzikofer'
title: b'very dark and depressing'
body: b'I dont understand the point of this book. It was filled with characters who were miserable. I had a hard time keeping up with all the characters thrown at you in the beginning. Very depressing. I love to read and escape, but this was just so dark and dirty. No one seems to learn their lessons. Maybe I am not looking "deep" enough. Also would not let a child or teenager read this. Very strong language, sex, drugs, rape and abuse.'

author: b'Pen Name'
title: b"Very different from what you've come to know and expect from Rowling."
body: b'I have to start out by saying what a huge fan I am of J.K. Rowling, because I feel that may help some people understand my review better.  I\'m a HUGE Potter fan, I re-read the series regularly and have been anticipating the release of any new book by Rowling for the past 5 years.  That being said, I didn\'t expect this book to be anything like Harry Potter plot-wise, or even in theme.  I was super-excited about something completely new from J.K. Rowling.  Regardless of what anyone says of her prose in her previous series I always found something sparkling and intoxicating in her writing style and characterizations.  So I eagerly purchased the Casual Vacancy on the first day of its release, and launched into it like a child greedily rips open presents on Christmas morning.  If anything asserts the distinction that this is not Harry Potter or any other book for young readers its the immediate and excessive usage of loose profanity, rampant drug and alcohol abuse and sexual depravity.  We are launched into the mind of every single character we encounter at some point, viewpoints shifting back and forth dizzyingly.  This allows us a unique access to their thoughts and backstories, and this third-person omniscent is very contrary to the third-person limited we experienced in her series.  Being a lover of minute details and normative everyday activities and thoughts, I was prepared to love this in every way.  You have to understand how much it pains me to say that I don\'t think I do, I feel the need to love it, to defend Jo Rowling and all her brilliance, but I think it would be "inauthentic" of me to claim it.  To me it feels like there\'s something missing.  This book is so dark and gloomy and heavy, and perhaps its meant to be after years of writing good-natured comedy and happy endings.  However the heaviness is wearing, and I found myself returning relentlessly back to the book, not as I have to all her others in avid anticipation of what would happen next, but with a sense of duty.  Though the characters are not wholly uninteresting, there\'re all seriously flawed in one way or another (which may be more true to life) but which makes it difficult to really find any of them likable and sympathetic, though it gets easier towards the end.  Something I missed here too was Jo Rowling\'s talent to easily weave seemingly small, but vastly important details into the story and keep them hidden there for later discovery and impact.  She does much less vivid a job creating a physical world for us under the assumption we can just see the small town without fresh and fruitful descriptors, and as a result the town seems flat, the homes nearly indistinguishable.  For me, the spark was missing, and throughout at least 90% of the novel I could scarcely believe it was authored by J.K. Rowling.  And though I\'m sure she\'s intentionally moving away from and editting her writing so it doesn\'t match Potter, the attempt to redefine seems to rob some of the best qualities of Jo Rowling\'s writing.  Overall, it\'s okay, not completely unenjoyable, has some really poignant and heartfelt moments, but definitely isn\'t for everyone and won\'t inspire the cult following of her previous series; which may have been Jo\'s intentions all along.'

author: b'Stone'
title: b'Sad face...'
body: b"What a huge disappointment coming from one of the best story tellers of her generation. I knew going into the book to put Harry Potter up on the shelf; this was NOT a wizarding experience. But what I wasn't expecting was boredom and run-of-the-mill story telling. Unfortunately this book is just like every other who dunnit out there! Ms. Rowlings, you have a unique talent for creating fantasy. Go back to your roots - I'm sure there's another Harry Potter in you somewhere!"

author: b'Jaimie'
title: b'Wonderful characters'
body: b"I woke up at 2:30am, BING, and finished reading this book. I really enjoyed it, although it's not flawless and gets a little S.P.E.W. in places. This was exactly what I wanted to read, a kind of modern day Dickens/Austen thing. The characters were so engrossing, even the characters I have nothing in common with - Gavin, Samantha, Kay, Cubby. I'm going to miss them. Jo, you've done it again!"

author: b"CJCACC 's mom"
title: b'Not worth the trouble'
body: b'Honestly, I am a huge J.K. Rowling fan, that is the only reason I finished the book.'

author: b'Charlene'
title: b'Thought-provoking, character-driven drama about real-life issues'
body: b"This is nothing like Harry Potter.  Okay, I knew that, but deep down I was envisioning some of the ... magic in the world of Harry Potter would be evident here - but this is truly an adult book where honesty is more valuable than beauty.  It's real life, and it's harsh.  It was a little difficult to get into because of the vast array of characters who interact against the backdrop of the parish council election.  And J.K. Rowling takes her time masterfully shaping and delineating each character, creating a characteristically intricately plotted story which weaves the lives of at least twenty people into a varied, lively tale of the every day.  This novel is like a soap opera full of drama, petty jealousies, sex, drugs, abuse and adolescent rage.  Every private thought is revealed to the reader through the omniscient narrator making every failing of each character clear."

author: b'JJulieJ'
title: b'Dull, Dismal and Disappointing!'
body: b"The Casual Vacancy is a dull and dismal book, about dull and dismal people living in a dull and dismal village. I did read it right though to the bitter end, hoping and hoping for one tiny gleam of brilliance among the dross. I didn't find it and I didn't enjoy it."

author: b'D. N. Stone'
title: b'Her Masterpiece'
body: b"Another classic from J.K. Rowling.  I haven't been so consumed by a novel since The Help.  It's a sharp take on modern English village life and the need for compassion. Expect a lot of discussion of OCD in the coming months as more people read the book. It's not just about washing hands I learned, and JK says she suffered from it when"

author: b'Elizabeth'
title: b'Black but not magic'
body: b"I gave into temptation and bought 'The Casual Vacancy' minutes before it was released on Kindle. It was not long before I regretted my impulsive buying. Some of the language I found to be rather contrived and forced. A minor detail. At times the writing lost its forward flow. Again, a minor detail. Certainly there was the promised humour but with a flippancy that seemed to remove reality from the characters. It was not long before the characters' lives exposed themselves for what they were or for what they were to become, humour being overtaken by the stark reality of gloom and doom. This was to be the focus of the much larger part of the book and  made the book as a whole seem out of balance. The endless, sordid and squalid misery in the lives of the over-ample sufficiency of characters presented me with nothing beyond my awareness of life for some people. A year of Coronation Street on paper. Here was an opportunity to offer our troubled society some possible solutions for consideration. But, alas, this did not happen."

author: b'Cody Rodgers'
title: b'Adult per-se...'
body: b'This is not an adult novel, this is just an adult trying to be crass, vile, and bring sex/exploits/etc. into a horrible plot and storyline. I never did like her writing style for the Harry Potter books, but I thought hey - she is only writing to kids (specifically) so do not get held up on the childish grammar and writing skills, but this continues to show that she really is not a good author. Period.'

author: b'S. McKinney'
title: b'A hot mess worth zero stars (spoiler alert)'
body: b'I was interested in reading what JKR had to say as an adult novelist - my kids grew up along with Harry Potter, and although I loved those books, I thought that a writer of her prodigious talent would probably be able to pull off a non-Potter adult novel with ease.'

author: b'Eric C Wilder'
title: b'Not good'
body: b'Too many characters. Not very compelling. Certainly not worth the price of admission. Check out the book from the library if you really must read it.'

author: b'dpm'
title: b'Love it, Love JK Rowling.'
body: b'Amazing writer, amazing book.  She has such insight into human nature.  I am enjoying every minute.  Her character development, and the way she weaves the characters together, is truly remarkable.'

author: b'slim'
title: b"JK- Go back to writing children's books, please!"
body: b"I wanted to like this book. I wanted the writing to be just as page-turning as the Harry Potter books. I figured JK Rowling's writing style wouldn't change a whole lot just because it changed age levels, but I was wrong.  DEAD wrong."

author: b'Beth Smith'
title: b'Awful'
body: b'I was excited to read an "adult" J.K. Rowling book and for the first time pre-ordered a Kindle book. I checked my Kindle the first thing in the morning on release day to get started. By the way, yes, I\'ve read 6 of the 7 Harry Potter books (didn\'t read the 1st one.) I slogged through the 1st 1/3 of the book and then skipped to the last few chapters just to see how it all turned out. It wasn\'t that interesting or well-written and I hated all the foul language, the depressing characters and the topics in the book. I feel like I\'ve been duped by J.K. Rowling and my respect for her as a writer has plummeted. If I ever read another of her books, it will only be after I\'ve checked the reviews and the book has been out for awhile.'

author: b'Rhino'
title: b'Get the Audiobook - Well worth it!'
body: b'I\'m surprised the reaction to Rowling\'s first adult novel has been so tepid.  Yes, the book is nothing like "Harry Potter", but it is so impressive in its own right.  I\'m actually a huge "Harry Potter" fan, but those were young adult books, and while they displayed JK Rowling\'s humor, memorable characters, excellent plotting, and fabulous imagination, they didn\'t give as much scope to her talent as a realist, satirist, and acute observer of human nature.'

author: b'Terry Stagg'
title: b'Read before you review!'
body: b'I never write reviews, but I feel like I need to comment. All those that said " I read the sample, and this is what I thought...." I say "Sit down and shut up." Nothing sounds more stupid, oh except " I hate the price." If you are going to write a review  worth reading I would like to hear that you stuck with it until the end.'

author: b'Wallaby'
title: b'Like a PBS series about a small English village-  with complications'
body: b'We were all warned that this is an adult novel,  and not a sequel to Harry Potter.  This is a very readable story about a beautiful village, Pagford and a large cast of flawed people.  You will find authentic British vocabulary here,  which I find delightful.  Other cranky Americans will gripe about minivans called  "people carriers"  and high school called  "fifth and sixth forms"  and the like.  Anyway the Council Head  (that\'s a city councilman for you testy Americans)  drops dead and the political wranglings and personal struggles of many residents makes for a British Miniseries novel.'

author: b'Jo D.'
title: b'A great novel for grown-ups.'
body: b'So this is what real life is like after \'Dumbledore\' dies -- or in this case, the excellent and upright councilman, Barry F. Without his empathy and intervention, everything goes from bad to worse in Pagford in this very grown-up novel from Rowling, who proves herself a very able writer indeed in this realistically depicted tragedy of modern-day politics and class antagonism. I found this book entirely engrossing, with well rounded characters with mostly believable obsessions and hang-ups [though for my taste Colin, or "Cubby", the deputy schoolmaster, was a little too Wing Biddlebaum for me to quite believe]. I was impressed that Rowling was so very in control here not just of her sentences [I only spotted one real clunker] but of her excellent imagery and tone. Her bleak view here is entirely intentional, as her last-minute leavening of an otherwise unremittingly tragic ending with a well told reminiscence shows us. And what is she trying to show? Well, when the little tike who fantasizes about the speed of real cars by saying, "Broom! Broom!" [in a quick nod to Harry\'s Nimbus 2000] meets such a sad final fate, Rowling is clearly letting us know that our magic-free world can only be improved incrementally and through the faltering efforts of rightminded individuals like the much missed Barry, so much do we depend on each other, despite all our flaws. Change is hard, so we need empathy to cut through our own vacancy and apathy and spur us to help, even when such help seems even less than pointless given the enormous weight of suffering on the one side and the forces of social injustice aligned to protect the status quo on the other.'

author: b'Amazon Customer'
title: b'The Casual Vacancy from start to finish-4 and1/2 stars'
body: b"The Casual Vacancy is quite a departure from the author's previous books, of course, and is sure to irritate and anger some of her fans, but it should find its own audience quickly. The characters in this novel have nasty little secrets and the death which opens the story serves to reveal their many flaws. All of this makes Rowling appear more cynical and less humorous than in the Harry Potter series, and the book did start to feel very dreary about one third through. But I soldiered on, confident that the feeling of being in the hands of an excellent storyteller I had enjoyed during the opening pages would pay off. And it did. The resolution, while tragic, was satisfying and the changes that characters exhibited were believable and touching. I think her characters rang true and even though their lives were rather sordid, I didn't feel that the book itself was. It made for an engrossing, thought-provoking read. I would recommend it, but read the synopsis and don't expect anything magical other than Rowling's deft ability to expose a character's innermost secrets with precision and wit."

author: b'KennethHarmon'
title: b'Even Legends Can Stumble'
body: b"You can count the number of authors who successfully made the jump from children's fiction to adult fiction on one hand. The differences between the two are too vast and too hard to master. You can add J.K. Rowling to the ranks of authors who tried and failed. Her writing style is a perfect fit for children's fantasy, but does not work here. She tries too hard to make the jump and as a result has written a book that will soon be forgotten. I read this week that Rowling might write another Harry Potter book. I hope that is the direction she chooses, because adult fiction just isn't her cup of tea."

author: b'Kindle Customer'
title: b'Who does she think she is $17.99 for an e-book!!!!!'
body: b'I only gave her one star because my system would not take no stars!  Does she forget what it was like to be poor and homeless?  The book is horrible top!'

author: b'jecb'
title: b'in response to the one star reviews'
body: b'i have to say, i was completely taken aback by the number of negative reviews of this book. when i read them, however, it was clear to see that many of the people doling out a single star did not even finish it, and many more were essentially disappointed they were not reading another harry potter book.'

author: b'reading matters'
title: b'Complex, gritty, thought-provoking book'
body: b"The author is a keen observer of the human heart and human interactions.  JK brings us inside character's minds to hear the stories they tell themselves. The characters' inner fiction then drives the myriad of tragic-comedic events in the book.  This is fascinating and believable literature."

author: b'C. F. Crowe'
title: b'Missing pages'
body: b'The Kindle version of this book included 323 pages , the print copy contains 502 pages.  Comparing. page content shows that the Kindle version has fewer words per page.  Does this indicate two versions of this title?'

author: b'Pendragon'
title: b'Like banging your head against a brick wall.'
body: b"Just like banging your head against a brick wall, it's wonderful when it's over."

author: b'Kindle Customer'
title: b'Wonderful book'
body: b"It did take me a bit of time to get into this book, mostly because of who the author is and how different the characters are  from the beloved Harry Potter.  But at some point, not sure when, I got so absorbed in the story  I forgot who wrote it. The characters are so finely drawn, so real, the story going towards an inevitable end, almost like watching an accident about to happen when you can do nothing about it. I couldn't put it down."

author: b'T. Nelson'
title: b"If you're expecting an adult HP, you won't like it"
body: b"I am a huge HP and JK Rowling fan.  But, I also read the previews and knew that this book would be completely different from HP. So, I went into it with an open mind.  If you are expecting typical JK Rowling fare, you will not like this book.  Most of the negative reviews appear to be from these type of people.  They also didn't give it enough of a chance.  It is impossible to accurately assess a story that you do not finish.  This is particularly true here."

author: b'delanolady'
title: b'The Casual Vacancy is a winner for me!'
body: b'I just finished reading this book. I couldn\'t put it down. The lives of the characters ring true to me, probably because I taught quite a few students who were "Krystal". I purposely did not look at some of the other reviews, but one reviewer seemed to be offended by some of the events taking place in the book. I hate to say this, but there are more "Krystals" than you probably know out there and they are quite desperate people. Ms. Rowling\'s characterization is true to me in all respects, but then I live in a small American town. We have all the same people here, we have "projects" and "welfare moms" nearby in a slightly larger town. Her description of political maneuvering in elections in small towns is exceptionally honest as is her portraiture of adults who cannot control computer sites as well as the teenagers involved. (But then I worked with teachers who did not know how to turn on their own computers, but I digress.)Throwaway children die every day and no one helps them, because they are dirty and smell bad. Teenagers commit suicide and cut themselves because of family problems. If you want fantasy, read the Harry Potter books. This book is very true to life and not just true to England. It could be set anywhere.'

author: b'JCStreetSoldier'
title: b"Don't jump on the bandwagon until you're informed"
body: b'PRE-VACANCY:'

author: b'J. Brandt'
title: b'As much as I tried to enjoy this book....3 stars is generous at best'
body: b'I bought this book the day it came out. I just finished it and I can honestly write that I struggled to finish it as I found myself'

author: b'Macon_Mandy'
title: b'Rowling does it again!!'
body: b"I'm a huge HP fan and was terrified I wouldn't like this new book, but I absolutely loved it. It goes without saying that this is not a children's book. This is not Harry Potter. This book is just real."

author: b'Saga Ruby'
title: b'Not my cuppa'
body: b'So expensive. So eagerly awaited. So disappointed.'

author: b'Linda Joy Singleton'
title: b'Great Writing'
body: b"I stayed up late to finish J.K. Rowling's newest book ... sound familiar?"

author: b'invisiblgirl'
title: b"If you're reading this review, you're smarter than me"
body: b"I pre-ordered the book, even though the description didn't exactly tantalise, because it was written by an author who could make a grocery list interesting.  I should have waited for the reviews and saved myself $17.  The real JK Rowling is an author with wit and a love for wordplay.  Even her minor characters are so well-drawn, they could carry a book on their own."

author: b'S.Hocking'
title: b'You should not compare it to HP'
body: b"I will keep this short. I think Miss Rowling has done an excelent job with this book. The characters are down to earth as well as cleverly interlinked with each other. I am not even half way through but I am looking forward to finishing the book. The only reason why I haven't finished it is because I am studying a degree along side it."

author: b'Michael'
title: b"Not so casual vacancy in J.K. Rowling's brain - shockingly arrogant, very angry leftist drivel..."
body: b'The author is hell-bent on making you feel guilty and responsible for all the lowlife of this world. I am sure that you will learn nothing about the real British town from this book. What you will learn is that J.K. Rowling is a pathetic, dark, very angry, leftist demagogue. She could be a speech writer for the Obama White House.'

author: b'mfch'
title: b'real, raw, tragic, and nothing like Harry Potter'
body: b"Another review here from someone who has actually read the whole book. And I do feel like I should offer some sort of disclaimer here- I am a huge Harry Potter fan and grew up with the books. However, Harry Potter has not blinkered my reading career, as much as I loved the books, I love other books more and am currently doing my literature degree at university. I feel like this is important to mention because whilst J.K Rowling's name drew me to the book in the first place, it is not what made me read it and not what made me enjoy it."

author: b'Dranea79'
title: b"I wish we didn't have to enter in a star rating"
body: b"If I had to go off my own enjoyment factor, I would rate it a one. If I am rating it based on the writing, I give it three stars. But seeing as I think I should write the review based on both, so I will give the star rating based on writing and my one star review in here.  :)  Seeing as there are numerous reviews already, I won't go into a synopsis of the book as I do in so many of my other reviews - so I'll just get to the meat of everything."

author: b'Scorpio Dragon'
title: b'Kindle is Too Expensive'
body: b'OK I realize this is a new release, but that does not excuse ripping off the customer for eBook version.  Maybe if the publishers were not so heavily invested into the printing press companies (Many own their presses and they are losing money big time) we would not have to pay for your losses.'

author: b'Sho'
title: b'Better than I anticipated'
body: b'Does this sound about right? "Rowling\'s refusal to conform to happy endings demonstrates the fact that The Casual Vacancy is not meant to be entertainment. She wants to deal with real-life issues, not the fantasy world to which women writers are often confined. Her ambition is to create a portrait of the complexity of ordinary human life: quiet tragedies, petty character failings, small triumphs, and quiet moments of dignity. The complexity of her portrait of provincial society is reflected in the complexity of individual characters. The contradictions in the character of the individual person are evident in the shifting sympathies of the reader. One moment, we pity Stuart, the next we judge him critically."'

author: b'Library Lady'
title: b'Sad and Disgusted'
body: b'I was so excited to read another J.K. Rowling. H.P. was a classic. But I was SEVERELY disappointed. so much foul language, SO much explicit filth. A good writer can use allusion without searing images of crass drivel being poured onto the page. I bought the kindle edition and could only make it to 13% before I had to put it away. I was sick to my stomache. I truly hope Rowling will return to something else next time, even if its not Harry. I feel like she was trying to move out of the pigeon-hole YA genre and went over the cliff in the opposite direction.'

author: b'Rami Yoakum'
title: b'Are you kidding me?'
body: b"$17.99 for an electronic pulse? And people are paying that price? What's the old saying... a fool and his money are soon parted. Duh!"

author: b'DarnGood'
title: b'Masterpiece Theater 2012 or Mystery Science Theater 3000??'
body: b"Well then, wasn't that interesting.  Love you JK and this is a well written book, as demonstrated by the revulsion along with the inability to stop reading.  But in Pagford you are either abusing or being abused by someone.  This is the predictable small town minutiae, with the gossip, waring factions, family disfunctionality, and tragic outcomes that pepper the news reports in the evening. Unfortunately in times like we are in where people need something uplifting, and inspiring us to the better angels of our nature, we are shellacked with a modern day dickensian david copperfield, in the most groveling human interactions."

author: b'M. Johnson'
title: b'The Casual Vacancy'
body: b"Well, I'll start with the obvious, in case anyone has yet to hear: this is definitely NOT Harry Potter for grown ups. It is proper English Literature. Oh, there are ghosts, though. The_Ghost_of_Barry_Fairbrother is all too flesh and blood, however. It is the study of a small town and what happens to that town when it loses its touchstone, in the form of the death of Barry Fairbrother. It is both a laugh track and a gut punch. Not something I probably would have picked up without JK Rowling's name attached, but I'm glad that I did."

author: b'Andrew'
title: b'this book is just like harry potter!'
body: b"a lot like harry poitter, especially the part about the snake!  and the magicless wands, can't wait for the next 6 books.  i even liked the swearing!"

author: b'LLCox'
title: b'What a waste!'
body: b'This book was a great disappointment. The only reason I read the whole thing is because I paid so much for it. The whole book was full of miserable people doing bad things to each other. Really, she should not have written this!'

author: b'*Caligirl_08*'
title: b"I really don't understand why everyone is hating on this book so much???"
body: b"I am only 1/3rd of the way through but I really felt like I had to come on here rush to this book's defense. Yes, IT IS NOT Harry Potter (but actually, the characters and personality from those books are still present in this book.) I love the humor and the unique way JKR has of depicting her characters and breathing them life. My favorite character so far is Fats. I would compare this book to Zadie Smith's"

author: b'Brendan McGregor'
title: b"Don't listen to haters."
body: b"Fantastic read. Just don't be one of these fools that pick it up expecting HP. Its an absolute page turner."

author: b'Bobbie'
title: b'Amazing Author'
body: b"I think J K Rowling is a brilliant writer and I would have bought this book if it were $117.99 and written in pencil on toilet paper. It is distressing that readers punish the author for the greed of the publishers. I had no idea what to expect and for some reason I was thinking Agatha Christie or PD James. Truth is, it was more like Salinger or Vonnegut, harsh realism and depressing insight into human weaknesses. The book is gritty, dark, humorous, and too believable. The characters are real, fragile, not likeable, and for the most part doomed. Rowling's writing is seamless and drags you in. Just like Harry Potter, you feel as if you know these people. You wish you could shake them, kill them, or help them. I couldn't put the book down. I can't say I enjoyed it, rather I experienced it and I am sure I will be thinking about it for a long time to come. As I mentioned before, I think Rowling is brilliant and this book solidifies my feelings. She is an amazing author, with an incredible mind. I would highly recommend the book. It is something you shouldn't miss."

author: b'corango'
title: b'a waste of money'
body: b'This book is so disappointing. i love thrillers and drama books. I had hoped that some of the magic that this author had produced in her harry potter series would spill over and produce something really special. This book is boring, uninteresting, slow and a waste of my 24 dollars. I suppose it wasnt a waste because i know now that i wont spend any more money on her next book.'

author: b'Ben Shearon'
title: b'The price is insane'
body: b"Okay, I'm interested. Enjoyed the Harry Potter series. Like what I've seen of Ms Rowling in public. Book sounds interesting."

author: b'Astralwolf37'
title: b'Apparently Wizards are Only Allowed to be Interesting and Likable'
body: b"I read a good chunk of this at the bookstore to see if it would be something that is worth the $30+.  I never made it through the whole thing, so I'm not the best judge on the overall plot, but I can say unequivocally that the writing style is flat and the characters are dull and unimaginative.  Many people seem concerned that the book is being compared to Harry Potter too unfairly, but the author's previous work shows us what she is capable of, and she is falling short by miles and miles."

author: b'Happy reader'
title: b'Dark, angry, ugly'
body: b'An utter disappointment from JKR after her phenomenal success. Dark can be wonderful, but here it is merely pedantic and pointless.  An entirely uninspired book from start to finish.'

author: b'A. Prentice'
title: b'A Very British Novel; A True Heroine'
body: b"This is a novel in a very English tradition; it has echoes of Dickens, of George Meredith, of Evelyn Waugh. Post-World War II, it has notes of John Mortimer's Paradise Postponed and more than a few hints of Martin Amis. Rowling sets her nominally political tale about a local concil election in a setting that contains both the beauty of a traditional English village - Pagford - and the grit of an industrial city - Yarvil - inextricably linked, as the history of England includes the green and pleasant lands and the dark Satanic mills. She people both towns and tells the interwoven tales of many families, contrasting the middle class and the poor. What is unique about this book are the combined voices of the teenagers who inhabit it: Krystal, Andrew, Sukhvinder, Fats, and Gaia. These are young people struggling to survive and find a way to successful adulthood - some will make it and some won't. While Rowling can be somewhat humorous in portraying the imperfect adults in this novel, she is serious about the children and depicts them with knowledge, empathy. The most poignant character is the most desperate, Krystal Weedon, who came to remind me in many ways of Bill Sykes' Nancy. She is a true English heroine for modern times. The conversations of flawed parents and their desperate children are gripping and memorable. I cried at the end of this book and I'm not sure at all why reviewers are calling it a black comedy.  The images of Krystal and her young brother Robbie at the end of the book will stay with you for a long time. HIghly recommended."

author: b'Mary Whipple'
title: b'"You think reality is up for negotiation, that we think it\'s whatever you say it is...You must accept that you are not God."'
body: b'(2.5 stars) Focusing on life in the very small community of Pagford, perhaps similar to the small communities Rowling herself knew as a child in Gloucestershire, Rowling emphasizes the pettiness, the rivalries, the back-biting, and the cruelties of "ordinary" life as people try to cope with the messiness of existence as it unfolds. There is no magic here to offer any hope of change, no wizard to sweep down and offer aid, either to the characters or to the reader, and as the action progresses, with its focus on the unpleasant and often violent aspects of many lives, the reader is forced to examine the elements of chance which can devastate everything that one might dream of.'

author: b'granm'
title: b'A No read'
body: b'This book is depressing, rude, flat, and totally a waste of time.  Rowling should go back to what she does best...because it is NOT this book!'

author: b'abcdefg'
title: b'Life is too short to waste my mind on this dirty book...'
body: b"This is so sad.  I can't finish reading this book.  I was so excited to read it but it is such a dirty book with sex, language and ugly people saying, thinking and doing ugly things that I know this isn't what I should be spending my time thinking or reading about.  As a Christian, I know I would be going against everything I believe in to be advocating this book by reading it. Why must such a talented writer waste her gift on something so trashy?  Is it not possible to write well AND cleanly?  i know it is...read CS Lewis, Mark Twain, Charles Dickens and countless other classic writers.  Sad."

author: b'Lori Wolf'
title: b'Way to expensive'
body: b'I would love to read this book. I am a J.K. Rowling fan. However,my rating of the book is due to the price. I think the price is way too high. Amazon is taking advantage of the J.K. Rowling name. I will read when it is as reasonably priced as other best selling books.'

author: b'Vanilla Mango'
title: b'trying to hard to be adult-ish'
body: b'This book really feels to me like a child actress posing for playboy when she turns 18 just to prove she is a grown up now.  I\'m only 26 or so pages into the book and really just contemplating not finishing it.  I don\'t mind "edgy" elements in a good plot and some hard reality to make a point in a story but this so far is like a string of the worst swears a kid can come up with to assert his adulthood. Maybe I\'ll update this if I read the rest of it, but from other reviews I guess I have rape, and child abuse to look forward to as the "plot?" thickens.....'

author: b'Lisa Brandt'
title: b'Not worth the Kindle price'
body: b"This is the most expensive Kindle edition I've ever bought, and I did so only because I consider J K Rowling an awesome writer and story-crafter based on the HP books, and I just had to read her first novel for adults."

author: b'Kelsey Clair'
title: b'The Casual Vacancy - worth a second read!'
body: b'I had the same feeling while reading this book as I get while reading Potter - every page is pure entertainment. I couldn\'t put it down, but was devastated to reach the end. It was definitely an enjoyable reading experience for me, and I look forward to reading it the second time around to see what details went in one ear (eye?) and out the other the first time. I actually LIKED how none of the characters seem \'likable\' in the beginning (and even when they were still that way at the end), and even though there are 15 or so "main" characters that the story revolves around, I found myself understanding and being able to relate to each one, and I think most people will too. With this book Rowling proves that she can be a master of reality as well as master of all things magical. A great work by a great author, it will not take long for my copy to become well-worn!'

author: b'Delighted, Tunbridge Wells'
title: b'A wonderful novel'
body: b"Never having read an HP, I wasn't sure what to expect. What I found was a masterpiece, a huge panorama of a small village, peopled by the whole social spectrum. It's a wonderfully humane book with moments of great sadness and great humour.  It may be presumptuous to say about an author who has sold 450 million books, but she is truly an amazing writer.  So many people have described the sadness of leaving HP, but I'm sure that for many there will be no less sadness after leaving Pagford and its population of real (warts and all) characters."

author: b'Jessica'
title: b'I really wanted to like it but....'
body: b"I tried soooooo hard to read this book.  After 60 pages, I gave up.  I really wanted to like it, as I am a HUGE Harry Potter fan, but alas, I could not.  I knew it wasn't going to be Harry Potter, but I didn't know it was going to be so unlikable.  The characters were all horrible people who I didn't care about.  There were long passages that made no sense.  I read them several times but never understood.  You practically need a dictionary to figure out what J.K. Rowling is saying.  I am an adult, but the foul launguage and crude sexual references were too much for me.  I couldn't figure out where the plot was or where the book was possibly going to I stopped reading.  I'm sorry to say it, but I think fans of J.K. Rowling are going to be let down! :("

author: b'edel'
title: b'JK Does It Again!!!!'
body: b'When Barry fairbrother dies, his death affects almost each family in each house of the town of Pagford either directly or indirectly. One thing I quickly learned is that this wonderful author can still write characters we all care about. The book is told in a way that almost each chapter is given to a different family and we are almost flies on the wall watching and observing what is happening behind the closed doors of the town. Needless to say there is many secrets and scandals hidden in this ordinary town. There is sexually explicit parts in the book , and violence, and sexual violence towards children, drug abuse, self harm etc etc. The story is just about as different from Harry Potter as you can get, but saying that, for a lot of the adult Harry Potter fans I think they will enjoy it as a lot of care obviously went into the characters ,and their lives as I as a fan of the HP series was used to.'

author: b'houstonbooklover'
title: b'Terrible book!!'
body: b"I was so looking forward to this book. I've read 100 pages and will not be finishing the book.  I don't like any of the characters so don't care what happens to them.  The story line is very dull and boring. It's very hard to believe that Rowling wrote such a disappointing book.  I found the language and sex to be offensive rather than adding anything positive or entertaining to the story.  Very depressing."

author: b'Silver Elm'
title: b'Brilliant!'
body: b"This book draws the reader in slowly. It's 500 pages, and plenty of time is given to get to know the various characters in the town and their stories and interconnections. Rowling creates a masterful web. After a certain point I couldn't put the book down--- the tension continues building and building all over the town, and I was desperate to find out what was going to happen to everyone, particularly with a couple of the characters that I cared about deeply, but also with a couple of characters I hoped to see fall!"

author: b'Connie'
title: b'Casual Vacancy'
body: b'She should stick to Harry Potter type books'

author: b'TK McEachin'
title: b"J.K. Rowling Fails This Time Around, but I'm Still Rooting for Her"
body: b'To start, this is my blog before I read a significant portion of the novel:'

author: b'Dorfy'
title: b'Huge Disappointment'
body: b"I was so happy that J K Rowling was offering us another book to read. I fully expected it to be as good, and maybe even better than her Harry Potter books. I couldn't believe that this book was from the same author. I finished chapter 4 and decided to read the reviews on the book to see if I wanted to continue. Maybe it would get better.
